Keywords: Integrated Care; Information Indicators; Healthcare Governance; Information Systems 1. Introduction Healthcare systems today face common challenges and unpredictable future, namely concerning the need to respond to a growing and more complex demand of care, in a context of new diseases, financial constraints and a decrease in the workforce motivation, which may raise questions about the sustainability of the current models. Hence, it may be necessary to move from a fragmented system to a more coordinated arrangement, which is the aim of integrated care [1,2]. The theme of organizational design and the issue of contingency in the best alternative choices for the design of healthcare organizations has evolved by incorporating concepts such as organizational homeostasis [3] or systems thinking [4,5] or recognizing that excellence is not the result of distinction in each function separately, but it has to consider the remaining stakeholders, including own employees, suppliers, customers, government and society in general [6]. Ureda and Yates [7], using the fundamentals of systems thinking, consider that systems must be able to guarantee anticipation, integrity, strength, and additional reserves to maintain their balance against the environment. Coordination with other systems allows them to develop the capacity to deal with future threats. Hence, the systems must look beyond stability. With regard to healthcare systems, as an alternative to systems oriented to professionals or to technologies, it is crucial to resort to a variety of mechanisms, from greater accountability of the parties, to a greater focus on the patient as a whole. In the words of Geddes and colleagues [8], the lack of an integrated strategy across policy areas serves to perpetuate and even increase the existing compartmentalization and polarization of sectoral interventions, thus decreasing the success of tackling inequalities and making healthcare systems more sustainable. This co-production of healthcare is enabled by the proliferation of new technologies and access to information [9,10], which create the framework for determining which policies can be designed, how policy objectives can be achieved and how short and medium-term deadlines can be established. In fact, problem identification and priority setting processes are based on existing healthcare system indicators. Accordingly, the existence of a set of indicators providing a comprehensive picture of the existing heath system situation enables further monitoring and evaluation of healthcare objectives and goals set up by a strategy or program [11]. The objective of the study reported by this paper was to assess the available information to support the management and evaluation of integrated care provision, by comparing the availability of a comprehensive set of indicators related to the integrated care provision with the availability of other healthcare provision indicators. In addition to this introductory section, the present article comprises four more sections: Background, to explain the current concepts related to the integration of care; Methods, to present the study design; Results, to include the results from the assessment of the availability of various healthcare provision indicators; and Discussion and Final Remarks, to discuss the results and to draw a conclusion. 2. Background According to the definition proposed by WHO, in 2008, healthcare integration is the â€œorganization and management of healthcare services so that people receive the care they need, when they need it, in a simple way, to achieve the desired results and ensure a cost-effective provisionâ€� [1,p.5]. The integration of care can be seen from different perspectives. The patients expect: coordinated services; that their time is valued; professionals who care about their health conditions as a whole and who are able to communicate with each other through the various healthcare levels (and beyond the boundaries of their institutions) relative to their cases. For providers, integration means that formally separated entities provide services jointly (or coordinated) managed, financed, and evaluated. At the macro level, both from the perspective of top management or policy makers, integration happens when decisions on policies, funding, regulation, or provision are properly connected [1,12]. The concept of integrated care is also related to the concepts of case management and disease management. In case management, there is a focus on the coordination of the various elements that make up the healthcare system. It requires the evaluation of multiple needs the patient may experience in the long term and it includes recommendations for care, monitoring and tracking of the patients, even when they leave the healthcare system. The goal is to avoid hospital re- admissions and the use of emergency services by individuals with multiple pathologies that require more intensive and continuing monitoring. It is a comprehensive and systematic process of screening, assessing, planning, organizing, coordinating, and monitoring the healthcare provision. This proactive process has four main objectives: to improve coordination, adequacy and consistency between services and systems; to increase patientsâ€™ choice and flexibility in providing services; to ensure a more cost-effective service and to improve outcomes for patients (e.g., quality of life, autonomy) [14]. Disease management is usually focused on patients with a single chronic disease, which, through a continuous and coordinated process of care, aims to improve the health status of specific population groups throughout the various stages of the disease. This segmentation of the population is made to chronic patient groups with increased risk of deterioration of their health status and that represent high costs for healthcare systems [14]. Tackling chronic disease in Europe is a big challenge in the organization of healthcare systems as well as in the definition of health policies. In this sense, as the latest economic and epidemiological analysis suggest [15], the priority should be the (integrated) management of the disease. However, in the lack of a single formula, the choice on the best or optimal combination of strategies is crucial [15]. It is widely recognized that health outcomes depend not only on healthcare services and their professionals but are also strongly conditioned by the context and behaviours of each patient. Another important aspect to be addressed will be the training of patients and families for the course of treatment, namely by providing information on how to manage their health conditions, and who to contact if needed. In this respect, four important areas are emphasized in assessing the quality of transitions: information transfer; preparation of the patient and caregivers, particularly the family; the ability to self-care management; and the patientsâ€™ ability to choose. In this respect, information transfer, medication instructions and treatment guides are particularly relevant when institutions and professionals work independently and communication between them is poor [16]. Successful management of chronic disease requires not only effective drugs, but also a greater capacity for self-management of the disease, specifically with respect to adherence to therapy [15]. It is also supported in the literature that the measures and methodologies to assess the performance of care providers that are traditionally used are consistent with a fragmented supply, which calls for the development of adequate measures for the systems systematic monitoring, crucial to support political decision [15,17]. A 1996 WHO report [19] had already addressed this issue and emphasized governance as crucial to ensure integration of care, proposing some guidelines for a national strategy and its action plan: the creation of a political and strategic infrastructure that reflects a real commitment of governments to the integration of healthcare; the regional assessment of health needs in order to match supply; the introduction of organizational and structural changes, which may involve a reorganization in the distribution of powers, in particular the granting of more power to the regions; the promotion of research in this area, namely to establish a monitoring system supporting the integrated provision of healthcare. Article [20] denotes that researchers appear to have been focusing their attention on the service delivery design of integrated care, with a current move toward the notion of person-centeredness as a way of modelling any aspect of processes and interaction with patients and their caregivers, a viewpoint that tends to increase the interdependencies between the different components of healthcare and social care systems. We recall in this regard the concept of Health in all Policies [21], which translates into the development of a horizontal health policy focused on identifying the factors that influence the health of populations, mostly conditioned by sectoral policies that go far beyond the healthcare sector. This approach assumes that health conditions are not only the result of the activity of the healthcare sector per se, but they are also determined by the living conditions and other socio-economic factors. Therefore, it has deep roots in public health and helps to strengthen the link between health policies and other policies in various sectors (e.g., social, agricultural, education, environment, transport, tax system). Such multisector approach adds new forms of governance, mainly by forging new strategic relationships, both within government and with non-state actors, to address the most challenging health problems. Even though the pace of change needed to address this new governance challenge is still in slow motion, namely in countries marked by a long tradition of centralized governance such as Portugal [22], such perspective is strongly underlined in most political agendas and supported by decision-makers [23]. As a result of the work of Dias and colleagues [24], a set of strategic dimensions were proposed for analysis and intervention in the integration of care, namely: governance; financing model; human resources; information management; client empowerment; structures and assessment. Governance and clinical integration emerge as critical aspects, undertaken as a means and an objective to improve system performance, which may be achieved through integrated disease management, case management and/or increased investment in self-care. On the strategic tie, there are four dimensions seen as enablers of clinical integration: financing model, human resources, client empowerment and information management. With regard to the structure for the integration of care it is reasoned that the formal integration is one possibility, but that it can also result from articulation or coordination experiments, in which processes assume a prominent position. For the performance evaluation, it is proposed to measure the outputs of healthcare integration efforts, through effectiveness and efficiency metrics. The integration of care can be assessed at the macro level (healthcare system), at the meso level (focus on healthcare organizations and the services they provide) and at a micro level (patient/career interaction). However, there is a lack of consolidated models for assessing the integration of care, with generic application in macro and meso levels, except for some specific programs or application areas. Moreover, there is a lack of large-scale studies, population-based, in the context of chronic disease [15]. This is based on the assumption that timely access to patientsâ€™ information can help to improve medical decisions and to manage the transitions of patients when necessary more effectively. Hence, many European governments have been supporting projects in health information systems, in particular the e-health platforms and electronic health records, to improve the sharing of information between healthcare providers, patients, pharmacists and other stakeholders. These platforms can incorporate from guidelines for health professionals to relevant information for the patients [16] and, also, can provide relevant indicators for the governance of healthcare provision. Methods As a starting point of the study reported by this paper, it was assumed that if the information available throughout the process of care is up-to-date and reliable, this will positively influence the planning and organization of the healthcare services, particularly with regard to referral of patients, and also to ensure greater consistency of care provision. Therefore, the objectives of the study were to identify for the NUTS 3 Region of Aveiro, Portugal, the available indicators to support the management and evaluation of integrated care provision, and to compare the availability of these indicators with the availability of other healthcare provision indicators of the same region. The study design included three phases: ï‚· Definition of the indicators. ï‚· Collection of these indicators for the Region of Aveiro, since 2011 till 2018. ï‚· Comparison between the availability of indicators related to the management and evaluation of integrated care provision and the availability of general healthcare provision indicators of the Region of Aveiro. In the first phase, 153 indicators were identified across four different categories: ï‚· The first category includes sociodemographic, social and economic indicators, such as: number of inhabitants, unemployment rate, level of education, gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, ageing index, mortality rate, natality rate, and life expectancy at birth. ï‚· The second category includes several indicators related to the demand for healthcare, such as: causes of death, preterm births, and number of patients enrolled in primary healthcare units. ï‚· The third category includes indicators related to integrated healthcare provision, such as the referral of patients among the different levels of the healthcare services. ï‚· The fourth category includes all the other indicators related to supply of healthcare, such as: number of primary care units, number of hospitals, numbers of continuous care, number of pharmacies, number of human resources per institution, number of appointments carried out by the institution, number of clinical procedures per type of intervention of the different institutions, the number emergencies, or number of hospitalized patients. This result confirms what is sustained in literature, that highlights the systems fragmentation in the performance assessment methodologies and measures and the unavailability of comprehensive information, which compromises the effective case management throughout the course of care, as well as independent evaluations and the backing for political decision-making [15,17]. The existence of a comprehensive set of healthcare data is a valuable information source that allows: healthcare managers to establish baseline conditions and highlight areas of concern, to recognize strategic changes which may be needed for the future course of actions and to improve human resourcesâ€™ management; and decision makers to indicate the results of action, to ensure that institutions can be held accountable to their plans, to assess current conditions and trends, to correct mistakes, and to reformulate ineffective policies. Governance is crucial to ensure integration of care and should be supported on adequate information indicators [19]. Previous studies on the governance arrangements within the Portuguese healthcare system show that health policies are still considered in a very centralized and hierarchical way, and very much within the healthcare sector boundaries (e.g. [22,25]). The pyramidal structure of the healthcare sector like a one-way passage and the inexistence of key indicators to strategically plan in advance health policies raise difficulties in fully implementing the policy agenda already mentioned. This result confirms what is sustained in literature, that highlights the systems fragmentation in the performance assessment methodologies and measures and the unavailability of comprehensive information, which compromises the effective case management throughout the course of care, as well as independent evaluations and the backing for political decision-making [15,17]. The existence of a comprehensive set of healthcare data is a valuable information source that allows: healthcare managers to establish baseline conditions and highlight areas of concern, to recognize strategic changes which may be needed for the future course of actions and to improve human resourcesâ€™ management; and decision makers to indicate the results of action, to ensure that institutions can be held accountable to their plans, to assess current conditions and trends, to correct mistakes, and to reformulate ineffective policies. Being acknowledged as an outcome of complex and dynamic relations stimulated by several social, environmental and behavioural determinants at different levels of policy intervention, healthcare also needs to be tackled in a comprehensive way [25]. Governance is crucial to ensure integration of care and should be supported on adequate information indicators [19]. Previous studies on the governance arrangements within the Portuguese healthcare system show that health policies are still considered in a very centralized and hierarchical way, and very much within the healthcare sector boundaries (e.g. [22,25]). Integrated care can be achieved by formal integration or from the combination and coordination of existing healthcare services. Irrespective of the possible approaches, integrated care demands efficient governance strategies in terms of planning and organizing care provision. Therefore, it is essential the existence of information (i.e., indicators) providing a comprehensive picture of the existing healthcare services, namely in terms of the quality of care integration. In this respect, the study reported by this paper aimed to assess the existing information indicators to support the governance of integrated care provision of the NUTS 3 Region of Aveiro, Portugal, by comparing their availability with other healthcare provision indicators of the same region. The results show that the indicators that are lacking focus mainly on continuous care, which means that the authorities do not have mechanisms to monitor, evaluate and improve the care integration, despite the respective emphasis in the political agenda. doc_title: Medical imaging data and process analysis in a stroke scenario
doc_abstract: © 2020 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.The quality of the healthcare provided in the context of cerebrovascular accident (stroke) is closely linked to the celerity of the diagnosis, so the action of health professionals must be coordinated, and all the processes should proceed as quickly, efficiently and effectively as possible. The main objective of the research study reported by this paper was to evaluate whether the data resulting from the processes related to urgent medical imaging studies of a medium-size hospital can support the characterisation of the procedures performed, as well as the identification of points of improvement, specifically in the context of stroke clinical situations. Data related to Head Computed Tomography (Head CT) and Angio Computed Tomography (Angio CT) studies carried out over a year (from August 1, 2017, to July 31, 2018) on 464 patients with suspected acute stroke were aggregated and analysed. The results of the statistical analysis of the duration of the different processes and subprocesses demonstrate significant variability (i.e., 47±37 minutes and median of 38 minutes for Head CT and 23±55 minutes and median of 13 minutes for Angio CT). According to the results, it seems that aggregated data from the different information systems supporting medical imaging procedures should be used for continuous practice improvement.

Introduction Waiting times in healthcare institutions are sometimes considerably high. Multiple factors, namely population growth and ageing, as well as the lack of infrastructures, will promote the increase of waiting times [1]. Concerning the emergency departments, often associated to significant delays in the provision of healthcare, their waiting times constitute an essential indicator since they influence the clinical outcomes [2-4]. Notably, the waiting time for a diagnosis is a crucial factor for early treatment [5]. For instance, when dealing with a cerebrovascular accident (stroke) the first three hours after the onset of symptoms are essential for the treatment, as this is the time window that allows the clinical procedures to be effective [5-7]. Among the various factors that impact the celerity and quality of a diagnosis, the availability of clinical information, including medical imaging information, assumes great relevance [8]. The rapid changes and technological advances over the last few decades are particularly relevant in the field of medical imaging, as its workflows are supported by information systems, which means that communication networks, accessibility, information quality and reliability are increasingly relevant [9]. Concerning medical imaging, in addition to the Hospital Information Systems (HIS) and Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems [10], the Radiological Information Systems (RIS), the Picture Archiving and Communication Systems (PACS), and, in some cases, the Teleradiology systems, contribute to the quality of the healthcare provision. These systems are responsible for the studies management, namely for archiving and communicating digital images produced by the multiple modalities of the medical imaging departments, as well as for the management of imaging procedures, registration of consumables and archive of clinical reports [11-12]. For the optimization of stroke diagnosis and treatment medium-size , the action of the healthcare professionals must be coordinated, and the processes proceed as quickly, efficiently, and effectively as possible [13-14]. Therefore, the existence of systems to notify suspicious cases is essential to optimize the processes, particularly before the patient arrives at the hospital [15-17], but also at the intra-hospital level, namely by notifying specific teams [18], as well as to monitor the duration of the different procedures [19-20]. Much of the pertinent information related to the stroke patients is distributed by the databases of various information systems, namely RIS, PACS, Teleradiology or EHR, so these systems are very relevant resources for collecting data pertinent for the analysis of the processes over time [20-21]. The main objective of the research study reported by this paper was to evaluate whether the data related to medical imaging studies in a medium-size hospital can be used to characterization the procedures being performed, as well as to identify points of improvement, namely in the context of the acute stroke diagnosis and treatment. Six sections compose this paper: in section two, the importance of the rapidly medical imaging studies execution in a stroke scenario, namely those related to Head Computed Tomography (Head CT) and Angio Computed Tomography (Angio CT) studies, is addressed; in section three the used materials and methods are presented; sections four presents the results; and section five is devoted to their discussion and to draw some conclusion. 2. Background The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the standard definition of stroke as a focal or global neurological impairment, of vascular origin, which can lead to stroke death, caused by an interruption of blood supply to the brain [22]. Stroke is currently the most significant cause of death across Europe and is also the leading cause of disability due to the countless physical, mental, and social sequelae, which restrict functionality in the adult population [23]. Several epidemiological studies, carried out worldwide, made it possible to calculate an average stroke incidence of 200 cases per 100,000 inhabitants per year [24-25]. In Portugal, given the relevance of a rapid provision of care to victims of stroke in the acute phase, the Stroke Green Way was created in 2008 [26]. It is a coordinated strategy to improve the referral and treatment of emerging patients, with a suspicious stroke clinical condition, in the pre-hospital, intra-hospital and inter-hospital phases [27]. Process mapping is an exercise to identify all stages and decisions of a process so that it can be continuously improved [28]. In the scope of healthcare services, process mapping is important as good processes tend to be translated into an overall improvement in the provision of healthcare [29]. On the other hand, process mapping allows to understand the reality of the services through the description of their functionality and workflows Diana Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 177 (2020) 363â€“370 365 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 3 management [30]. Moreover, the use of modelling and simulation tools for workflows allows both the analysis of workflows already implemented and their restructuring, as well as virtual simulation of new workflows, namely the ones required to carry out medical imaging studies [1,31]. Long waiting times related to a large flow of patients in need of care are also a common problem in medical imaging departments [31]. In the context of Heath CT studies requested by the emergency departments, the lack of response capacity in carrying out these studies can have a significant impact on patientsâ€™ waiting times [6]. Since inefficient management of workflows generates long waiting times and inefficient responsiveness in the provision of healthcare [32], the use of software tools to manage workflows might allow the balancing of workloads and can increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the available medical imaging services [33]. According to Goyal et al [7], detailed analysis of workflows with interactive feedback, as well as the establishment of time targets, can contribute to better outcomes. In this context, optimization procedures can promote the improvement of treatment duration and the potential for recovery [34-35]. The accurate and timely interpretation of Head CT studies in a stroke scenario contributes positively to treatment efficiency. Therefore, time management, teamwork and compliance with standardized institutional protocols, contribute to improve results. The existence of multidisciplinary protocols when performing Head CT in the context of acute stroke, seems to contribute to the reduction of response time, providing an improvement in clinical results [36]. The use of the data contained in information systems for the optimization of workflows, namely in terms of medical imaging, can be translated into added value for patients, particularly those with suspected stroke in the acute phase. 3. Materials and Methods The research study reported by this paper was authorized by the board of directors of a medium-size hospital after being approved by the respective ethics committee. The anonymity of the healthcare professionals and patients involved in the studies was fully guaranteed. Head CT studies carried out over a year on patients with suspected stroke, integrated into the hospital Stroke Green Way, were analysed in the period from August 1, 2017, to July 31, 2018. Initially, the mapping of the processes and information systems used to support the carry out of Head CT studies of patients with suspected acute stroke was done. Since in some stroke conditions it is also required Angio CT, the processes and information systems used to support the carry out of Angio CT studies were also mapped. Subsequently, data fields were identified belonging to RIS, PACS and Teleradiology databases. This allowed data aggregation for the characterisation of process and subprocesses associated to the Head CT and Angio CT studies performed in the context of suspected stroke in the acute phase. Finally, the duration of the different processes and subprocesses and their contribution to the development of alerts that could be used in the clinical context were analysed. 4. Results Head CT studies conducted on 464 patients were analysed: 245 (52.8%) males and 219 females (47.2%). Of these patients, 198 (42.7%) also performed Angio CT. When analysing the data related to the retrieved studies, a set of fields were identified in the RIS, PACS and Teleradiology databases and were considered to feed the Stroke Database after an anonymization process (Fig. 1). In terms of process characterisation, the request for the Head CT study carried out at RIS was considered the starting point. When the patient arrives at the CT room, requisition data is sent to the imaging equipment and the study is performed. At the end of the images acquisition, the study is considered completed being registered in the RIS as â€œexecutedâ€�. After the transmission of the images to the PACS database, the study is sent to the Teleradiology system. Depending on the results of the Head CT, the patient may be a candidate for Angio CT and endovascular treatment. Therefore, when an Angio CT is also required, it is performed after the realization of the Head CT. Discussion and Conclusion It is vital to build process maps in order to understand better the medical imaging workflows of a given institution, as well as identifying factors responsible for workflow congestion and possible points for improvement [6-7,29,32,33]. Within the scope of the research study reported by this paper, the processes mapping of the requisition and the realization of medical imaging studiesâ€™ of acute stroke victims enabled a better understanding of the paths taken by the patients in the hospital, particularly in the medical imaging department and regarding the Stroke Green Way initiative. There are studies that evaluate the average times associated to the realization of Head CT as well as studies that evaluate the elapsed time since the entry into the healthcare unit of patients with suspected stroke in the acute phase until the realization of the Head CT and the beginning of the treatment [6, 34, 36]. However, the processes that involve conducting studies in the context of acute stroke do not appear in detail in the literature [36]. In the case of the Head CT characterisation it was possible to identify procedures that can promote delays, which might negatively impact the diagnosis and treatment of patients with suspected acute stroke. The different databases that can be used to characterize the medical imaging processes makes it possible to identify situations that may represent points for improvement and to identify good practices to be emphasized and disseminate. In a context where it is imperative to have the diagnosis in the shortest possible time, it is essential that the results should be viewed holistically and considering that multiple factors can influence the celerity of the realization of the procedures. Some of these factors may be related to the availability of material and human resources, information assets, but also to the existence of efficient workflow processes in related areas, such as, for example, in the realization of clinical laboratory tests. Considering the results of the research study reported by this paper, it is possible to infer that the clinical databases have suitable data to characterize the duration of the different processes. The aggregation of data from different systems allowed to characterize the duration of the different procedures, but also to identify situations (individual and collective ones) that may deserve special attention. In this respect, carefully analyses should be performed about the causes of excessive delays that occurred for some patients. From the moment the study is requested until the patient enters the CT room (P1.1), there is significant variability in the time spent (SD - 28 min), and 25% of the patients wait more than 20 minutes before the beginning of the study. In this subprocess, the identification of a patient that wait five hours and 24 minutes entering the room may deserve special attention. The same reasoning can be used for the analysis of the other subprocesses. The use of statistical measures of dispersion allowed a global analysis of the times associated with the different processes and subprocesses, but also the identification of potential good practices. If the standard deviation values give a perspective of the variability associated with the performance of the procedures, the minimum values and those related to the 1st quartile (Table 2) values can be indicators of good practices, which may help to determine the factors that influenced a rapid realization of the procedures. On the other hand, the maximum values and the 3rd quartile may be pertinent for the identification of exceptional situations and may also be important for the identification of tendencies that can be associated to the adoption of inefficient procedural strategies. Regarding the studiesâ€™ execution time, the values obtained show that, in general, the processes are efficient, both in the Head CT study (average of five minutes) and in the Angio CT studies (average of ten minutes). However, for some patients, it was identified delays much longer than the average. Moreover, situations with minimum values of zero minutes were identified. These situations occur when the process is considered complete in one information system (e.g., RIS), but has not yet completed in another information system (e.g., PACS). Sometimes, for process speed optimization, the study is often Executed (considered as completed) at RIS even before the study acquisition completion at the equipment occurred and, consequently at the PACS. These scenarios promote sub-processes with minimum execution times of zero minutes. The time associated with some sub-processes carried out within the scope of the Stroke Green Way initiative, namely before the patient's arrival at the medical imaging department (e.g. patient transportation and laboratory data acquisition) contributes significantly to higher waiting time to diagnosis. The fact that the processes are all dependent on each other, a punctual poor performance in a specific subprocess can compromise the whole process, since it is the sum of the time spent in all processes that give the relevant data to determine how long it takes to conclude a diagnosis. There are also situations that may represent points for improvement, namely those related to situations that demonstrate the need for medical imaging department external processes improvement like, for example, those related with the referring physician department performance but also related with procedures taken before the patient arrives at the hospital [15-17]. The analysis of the of RIS, PACS and Teleradiology data and the statistical analysis of the duration of the various processes allow to infer the potential of their use in terms of continuous improvement of healthcare processes, namely those designed for potential stroke victims. As future work, we anticipate the relevance of developing automatic, real-time alert systems contribute to the promotion and adoption of best practices, as well as the identification of situations that may promote the deterioration of the health conditions of the patients as well as compromising their prognosis in multiple clinical contexts, namely beyond stroke. doc_title: The SOCIAL platform and the integration of internet of things devices to monitor activities and behaviors of older adults
doc_abstract: © Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.Current developments of healthcare technologies made possible innovative ehealth applications that provide the opportunity for personalized care in residential environments. The research study reported by the present chapter aimed to develop for the Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) platform, a platform of services to support the care and assistance of community-dwelling older adults, four types of Internet of Things (IoT) monitoring devices (i.e., contact-, motion-, pressure-, and power-monitoring devices) together with analytical procedures to infer important events that might characterize the health status of the care receivers. Moreover, the existence of platform mechanisms such as interoperability, authentication, authorization, logging, and auditing allows an interoperable and secure access to the processed information.

doc_title: Application of the ISO 9241-171 standard and usability inspection methods for the evaluation of assistive technologies for individuals with visual impairments
doc_abstract: © The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.This paper describes a usability evaluation process, based on ISO 9242-171 standard and inspection methods, to assess features to improve accessibility to information services by individuals with visual impairments. A usability evaluation process supported on a consistency inspection protocol conformed to the checklists provided by the ISO 9242-171 standard together with heuristic evaluation was applied to assess the accessibility of screen readers typically used by individuals with visual impairments. The results show that the approach proved to be adequate for supporting the assessment of accessibility features of the considered screen readers.

doc_title: Social care services for older adults: Paper registration versus a web-based platform registration
doc_abstract: © The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.Technological solutions have been playing an important role in health care provision and their implementation in social care area, though a bit slower, promises good outcomes in terms of the quality of care delivery. The study reported in this paper analysed the shifting process from a typical paper registration to a registration performed by a web-based platform (i.e., the Ankira® platform) in a Portuguese social care institution. In order to gather evidence and best practices, 13630 registries were analysed, 6390 in paper format and 7240 from the web-based platform. The results show that the shifting from paper to the web-based platform lead to a significant error rate decline in all type of registers, which demonstrates the significant impact of the introduction of information technologies to support social care provision.

doc_title: Enabling green building’s comfort using information and communication technologies: A systematic review of the literature
doc_abstract: © The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.The current environmental concerns increase the importance of sustainability in the construction industry. In this respect, information and communication technologies were identified to support automation and control systems promoting occupant’s comfort while safeguarding energy efficiency. In this study, a systematic review was performed to identify relevant applications supported by information and communications technologies with impact in the comfort of the occupants of green buildings. Results indicate that the scientific literature presents valuable arguments regarding the importance of information technologies to increase the occupant’s comfort and to minimize energy consumption of the modern green buildings.

doc_title: Prediction of Mobility Patterns in Smart Cities: A Systematic Review of the Literature
doc_abstract: © 2020, The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.This study aimed to identify the current approaches to determine mobility patterns using smart cities’ infrastructures, which might be useful to disseminate good practices. Therefore, a systematic review was performed based on a search of the literature. From an initial search of 8207 articles, 25 articles were retrieved for the systematic review. These articles reported different approaches to predict mobility patterns using smart city data sources, namely data from mobile carrier networks, from social networks or from transit agencies’ smart cards.

doc_title: DICOM Metadata Quality Analysis for Mammography Radiation Exposure Characterization
doc_keywords: Digital imaging and communication in medicines
doc_abstract: © 2020, The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.The usage of ionizing radiation on human tissues for medical purposes has been object of regular analyses using Digital Imaging and Communication in Medicine (DICOM) metadata. Particularly, the DICOM metadata related to mammographic studies has been used to support the monitoring of individual and population exposure. The objective of this work was to analyze the quality of DICOM metadata to characterize radiation exposure in mammographic studies performed during the first year of activity of a mammography equipment. Although DICOM metadata allow to characterize the radiation dose in mammographic studies, the results show that it is pertinent to effectively improve the quality of the stored metadata.

doc_title: System to Support Multidimensional Assessment of Human Functioning
doc_abstract: © 2020, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.Considering the importance of the assessment of human function, the present paper reports a research study that aimed to develop an information system to support a comprehensive set of clinical instruments. Following the requirements analysis, the system was implementing according the Model-View-Controller architecture. The system allows the selection of the most appropriate assessment instruments for a given patient the registration of the assessments carried out, as well as the access to consolidated information for correct decision-making, and was evaluated using quantitative and qualitative methods. The quantitative evaluation consisted in a usability assessment using the Post-Study System Usability Questionnaire, while the qualitative evaluation consisted in a focus group to determine the perceived utility of the developed system to support the care of older adults. The results show the potential of the system to support the care of older adults.

doc_title: A scale to assess the methodological quality of studies assessing usability of electronic health products and services: Delphi study followed by validity and reliability testing
doc_abstract: © Anabela G Silva, Patrícia Simões, Rita Santos, Alexandra Queirós, Nelson P Rocha, Mário Rodrigues.Background: The usability of electronic health (eHealth) and mobile health apps is of paramount importance as it impacts the quality of care. Methodological quality assessment is a common practice in the field of health for different designs and types of studies. However, we were unable to find a scale to assess the methodological quality of studies on the usability of eHealth products or services. Objective: This study aimed to develop a scale to assess the methodological quality of studies assessing usability of mobile apps and to perform a preliminary analysis of of the scale’s feasibility, reliability, and construct validity on studies assessing usability of mobile apps, measuring aspects of physical activity. Methods: A 3-round Delphi panel was used to generate a pool of items considered important when assessing the quality of studies on the usability of mobile apps. These items were used to write the scale and the guide to assist its use. The scale was then used to assess the quality of studies on usability of mobile apps for physical activity, and it assessed in terms of feasibility, interrater reliability, and construct validity. Results: A total of 25 experts participated in the Delphi panel, and a 15-item scale was developed. This scale was shown to be feasible (time of application mean 13.10 [SD 2.59] min), reliable (intraclass correlation coefficient=0.81; 95% CI 0.55-0.93), and able to discriminate between low- and high-quality studies (high quality: mean 9.22 [SD 0.36]; low quality: mean 6.86 [SD 0.80]; P=.01). Conclusions: The scale that was developed can be used both to assess the methodological quality of usability studies and to inform its planning.

doc_title: Web platform for the codification of observations and clinical interventions according to the international classification of functioning, disability and health
doc_abstract: © 2019 AISTI.This article reports a study aimed at developing a web platform that helps clinicians to code clinical observations and interventions according to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF).

doc_title: Chronic pain in high school students is associated with physical activity and sleeping hours but not with screen time

doc_areas.area_name: Public Health, Environmental and Occupational Health

doc_abstract: © 2019 Walter de Gruyter GmbH, Berlin/Boston.Existing studies on the association between physical activity (PA), screen based time and sleeping show conflicting results. This study investigates the association between chronic pain at different body regions and self-reported PA, screen based time and sleeping hours in high school students. A total of 969 students aged 13-19 years old. Participants completed a questionnaire on chronic pain, time spent in moderate and vigorous PA, screen based time watching televivsion (TV)/digital versatile discs (DVD), playing, using mobile phones and computers and sleeping hours. Univariate and multivariate associations between pain and PA, screen based time and sleeping hours were investigated. In the univariate model time spent in moderate and vigorous PA, in screen based activities and sleeping were associated with pain in at least one body site. In the multivariate model, screen based activities were not associated with pain; sleeping 7 h or less and increased time in moderate PA were associated with pain at almost all body sites [odds ratio (OR) between 2.69-3.66 and 1.06-1.10, respectively]. Time spent in PA and sleeping increased the risk of chronic pain in almost all body regions and might confound the association between screen based time and pain.

doc_title: The Social Platform: Profiling FHIR to Support Community-Dwelling Older Adults
doc_abstract: © 2019, Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.The care networks of community-dwelling older adults require cooperation between different actors, including health and social caregivers, assistant providers, care receivers, and their informal caregivers (e.g. relatives or friends), across time, space, and organizational boundaries. In this context, the project Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) aims at the development of a platform of services to support the care networks of community-dwelling older adults. Therefore, the study reported in this article assess the adequacy of the Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) to guarantee the interoperability of the relevant information related to the assisted persons of the SOCIAL platform, which are mainly older adults that need care and assistance services.

doc_title: DICOM metadata quality auditing for medical imaging stakeholders characterisation: a pilot study
doc_keywords: Digital imaging and communication in medicine metadatum
Digital imaging and communication in medicines
doc_abstract: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.The metadata that are part of a vast number of medical imaging exams might be a valuable source for medical imaging stakeholder’s characterisation. The study reported in this article aimed to assess the quality of Digital Imaging and Communication in Medicine (DICOM) metadata related to medical imaging stakeholder’s characterisation, particularly in terms of what attributes are available and their usage trends. The DICOM metadata of medical imaging exams carried out in a medium size hospital during a one-year period (i.e. 5 144 417 images, corresponding to 97 612 exams performed on 61 256 patients) were analysed. The results show that the use of the DICOM attributes for health care stakeholder’s characterisation varies with the medical imaging modalities, concerning the number of available attributes, and respective usage levels and data quality. Therefore, the filling in of DICOM metadata could be optimised, which may be relevant for the clinical practice as well as for the development of data bases that might support clinical research.

doc_title: Functioning and primary healthcare utilization in older adults: a 1-year follow-up study

doc_areas.area_name: Physical Therapy, Sports Therapy and Rehabilitation

doc_abstract: © 2018, © 2018 Taylor & Francis.Background/Purpose: Older adults are high users of healthcare services, mainly due to health conditions and their impact on daily activities, challenging the ability of health systems to provide timely and high-quality care. Conceivably, using disability-related variables to predict future healthcare utilization could contribute to reduce both older adults’ disability and healthcare costs. This study aimed to explore the association between aspects of disability and older adults’ primary healthcare utilization and hospitalization over a period of 1 year. Methods: Older adults (n = 129) were assessed for self-reported disability, lower limb performance, pain intensity and number of painful body sites, depressive symptoms, and self-reported physical activity. Data on primary healthcare utilization and hospitalization were collected for the period of 1 year through registries and phone interviews. Results: Regression analysis, adjusted for potential confounders, showed that self-reported disability and pain intensity were significantly associated with total primary healthcare utilization and together with a confounding variable (number of chronic conditions) explained 16% of its variance (p < 0.05). Increased physical activity was significantly associated with a decreased likelihood of being admitted to hospital (95% CI for exponentiation (B) = 0.27–0.81). Discussion: Data suggest that decreasing self-reported disability and increasing physical activity may decrease primary healthcare utilization and hospitalization, respectively.

doc_title: How Do Smart Cities Impact on Sustainable Urban Growth and on Opportunities for Entrepreneurship? Evidence from Portugal: The Case of Águeda
doc_abstract: © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.This chapter presents a case study that illustrates how the local structures of a developing medium-sized city in Portugal have been capable of, in times of public budget shortfalls, introducing structural changes based on the conceptualization of a smart city. Focusing on the case of Águeda, a city whose population is currently around 48 thousand inhabitants and whose economy is heavily based on manufacturing industries, with a predominance of micro-enterprises, the study explores how the concept of smart city has emerged and has been applied in a specific context and accordingly the extent to which public value has been generated.

doc_title: A Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) Implementation Integrating Complex Security Mechanisms
doc_abstract: © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.This paper reports an experimental study aiming to develop a platform of services, the Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) platform that integrates the Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) with authentication, authorization, logging and auditing mechanisms. The integration of FHIR with security mechanisms is described and a performance evaluation of the respective implementation is presented. The results show that the implementation is efficient in terms of information access by the different user-application pairs.

Introduction Nowadays, ehealth services are supported by multiple systems with overlapping functionalities. Therefore, interoperability is a key area to ensure harmonized solutions [1]. Concerning interoperability standardization, Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) [2] developed by Health Level Seven International (HL7) presents improvements when compared to existing solutions, namely HL7 Clinical Document Architecture (CDA) or HL7 Reference Information Model (RIM). In fact, FHIR allows concise and easy-to-understand specifications, as well as implementations based on well-established web standards (e.g. Extensible Markup Language â€“ XML, Java Script Object Notation â€“ JSON, or Representational State Transfer â€“ REST). In this way, FHIR is suitable for a variety of contexts [3]. The present article reports a study with the objective of using FHIR to guarantee interoperability of a platform of services, the Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) platform, aiming to provide information services to support integrated care and assistance of community-dwelling older adults [4]. Particularly, the integration of FHIR with complex authentication, authorization, logging and auditing mechanisms is described and a performance evaluation of the respective implementation is presented. 2. Related Work During the last decades, the exponential rise in computing availability, cheaper digital storage and broadband communications networking made possible the implementation of Electronic Health Records (EHR) across health care organizations. This evolution promotes patient-centered health care provision, by allowing different services to share clinical information [5]. Clinical information sharing is not seamless due to various technical difficulties, being information interoperability one of the major technical challenges. Interoperability problems go beyond the interoperability of hospital information systems because, as a consequence of the epidemiological transition towards non-communicable diseases, the remote care provision of chronic patients in their homes assumes a paramount importance. In this context, concepts such as â€œconnected healthâ€� or â€œholistic healthâ€� [6, 7] promote patient-oriented and holistic solutions to manage mutual awareness and shared objectives among care receivers and formal and informal caregivers [8]. These solutions require an effective cooperation not only among health care and social care formal caregivers but also among formal and informal caregivers, which is complex due to the lack of unified models, concepts and terminologies. To ensure reusability of information models and consistent definition of content and validation rules, there are different suitable models, such as CDA, Continuity of Care Record (CCR) or Continuity of Care Document (CCD). CDA intends to specify both the structure and semantics of the patientâ€™s data as a clinical document for exchange using HL7 v2 or v3 messages. In turn, CCR allows the capture of the patient health summary (e.g. problems, medications, allergies or care plans) together with current health status, and it is intended to improve continuity of patient care, by reducing medical errors and assuring a minimum health information transportability when a patient is referred or transferred [9]. Finally, CCD was developed by HL7 to combine the benefits of CCR and CDA [5]. Europe has also developed multiple health care standards, such as: Health informatics - Electronic Health Record Communication (EN 13606) [10], which defines an information architecture for communicating part or all EHR with other systems; Health Informatics - System of Concepts to Support Continuity of Care (EN 13940-1) to provide a standard terminology for planning, delivering and following-up the activities that form the continuity of care processes [11]; Health Informatics Service Architecture (HISA) [12], a standard based on service-oriented architecture (SOA) to provide guidance on the development of modular open information systems; and openEHR [13], an EHR specification and implementation based on the archetype concept. During the last years, FHIR has been subject of an increasing interest because it is based on web technologies and presents a focus on ease of implementation. These characteristics make development of models for clinical application easier for developers compared to more specialized and comprehensive models such as RIM or openEHR [1]. Concerning interoperability standardization, Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) [2] developed by Health Level Seven International (HL7) presents improvements when compared to existing solutions, namely HL7 Clinical Document Architecture (CDA) or HL7 Reference Information Model (RIM). In fact, FHIR allows concise and easy-to-understand specifications, as well as implementations based on well-established web standards (e.g. Extensible Markup Language â€“ XML, Java Script Object Notation â€“ JSON, or Representational State Transfer â€“ REST). In this way, FHIR is suitable for a variety of contexts [3]. The present article reports a study with the objective of using FHIR to guarantee interoperability of a platform of services, the Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) platform, aiming to provide information services to support integrated care and assistance of community-dwelling older adults [4]. Particularly, the integration of FHIR with complex authentication, authorization, logging and auditing mechanisms is described and a performance evaluation of the respective implementation is presented. 2. Related Work During the last decades, the exponential rise in computing availability, cheaper digital storage and broadband communications networking made possible the implementation of Electronic Health Records (EHR) across health care organizations. This evolution promotes patient-centered health care provision, by allowing different services to share clinical information [5]. Clinical information sharing is not seamless due to various technical difficulties, being information interoperability one of the major technical challenges. Interoperability problems go beyond the interoperability of hospital information systems because, as a consequence of the epidemiological transition towards non-communicable diseases, the remote care provision of chronic patients in their homes assumes a paramount importance. In this context, concepts such as â€œconnected healthâ€� or â€œholistic healthâ€� [6, 7] promote patient-oriented and holistic solutions to manage mutual awareness and shared objectives among care receivers and formal and informal caregivers [8]. These solutions require an effective cooperation not only among health care and social care formal caregivers but also among formal and informal caregivers, which is complex due to the lack of unified models, concepts and terminologies. To ensure reusability of information models and consistent definition of content and validation rules, there are different suitable models, such as CDA, Continuity of Care Record (CCR) or Continuity of Care Document (CCD). CDA intends to specify both the structure and semantics of the patientâ€™s data as a clinical document for exchange using HL7 v2 or v3 messages. In turn, CCR allows the capture of the patient health summary (e.g. problems, medications, allergies or care plans) together with current health status, and it is intended to improve continuity of patient care, by reducing medical errors and assuring a minimum health information transportability when a patient is referred or transferred [9]. Finally, CCD was developed by HL7 to combine the benefits of CCR and CDA [5]. Europe has also developed multiple health care standards, such as: Health informatics - Electronic Health Record Communication (EN 13606) [10], which defines an information architecture for communicating part or all EHR with other systems; Health Informatics - System of Concepts to Support Continuity of Care (EN 13940-1) to provide a standard terminology for planning, delivering and following-up the activities that form the continuity of care processes [11]; Health Informatics Service Architecture (HISA) [12], a standard based on service-oriented architecture (SOA) to provide guidance on the development of modular open information systems; and openEHR [13], an EHR specification and implementation based on the archetype concept. During the last years, FHIR has been subject of an increasing interest because it is based on web technologies and presents a focus on ease of implementation. These characteristics make development of models for clinical application easier for developers compared to more specialized and comprehensive models such as RIM or openEHR [1]. In addition, FHIR helps to bridge the gap to standard-based legacy systems by its ability to map to other HL7 standards, 526 Marco Rosa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 164 (2019) 524â€“531 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 3 such as the CDA and, as it is built to be supported by REST architectures and Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP), it is especially suitable for mobile applications [1]. Moreover, FHIR is an optimal standard for intermediate communication in terms of the complete communication chain from the personal health device up to complex ehealth infrastructures like hospital information systems or EHR systems [14]. Both are putting intense efforts in the integration of FHIR in their specifications for data exchange between personal health devices and health information systems. The basic building block of a FHIR document is a resource. Resources have a wide range of uses, from clinical content, such as care plans or diagnostics. Not fully compatible resources can be adapted to the desired context using FHIR extensions, which grants the ability to readjust the existent structure to one that fits specific requirements [1]. In turn, FHIR documents are built from a set of resources that, either by themselves or combined, satisfy the majority of common use cases. If interoperability standards allow the transfer and share of clinical information, it should also be kept in mind the need to consider authentication, authorization, logging and auditing mechanisms to ensure privacy, integrity and confidentiality of personal information. In this aspect, control mechanisms such as Attribute-based Access Control (ABAC) or Role-based Access Control (RBAC), and technologies such as blockchain [15] or eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) [16] have been applied to avoid unauthorized accesses of EHR [17, 18]. Therefore, the present study aimed to evaluate the performance of the information transfer mechanisms that were implemented for the SOCIAL platform, which has an FHIR gateway with suitable security mechanism to provide interoperable care receiverâ€™s information. 3. Proposed Solution Different types of services are required for the care networks of community-dwelling older adults, from complex health care or social care services to simple specialized assistance services such as, for example, housekeeping. For that, several interacting organizational structures may co-exist, including formal care networks (e.g. health or social organizations and caregivers), regulated by collaboration contracts or agreements, a wide range of public and private services and assistant providers (e.g. transport services, namely personal transportation and delivery of goods at home, or assistance providers addressing less tangible values such as participation, including social, religious, civic and political participation of older adults), informal care providers resulting from a diversity of community-oriented structures (e.g. relatives, friends, voluntary groups or non-governmental organizations), and authorities and supporters dealing with socio-economical and legal context of care provision, including legislative and public welfare organizations, financial bodies or supporting organizations. In particular, it was considered the need of customized and personalized user interfaces with consistent look-and-feel interaction and navigation across all the applications. Moreover, the integration of information from public and private institutions with different professional, organizational and jurisdictional nature requires reliable interoperability mechanisms, which means that both the technologies being used, and the understanding of the collected information, processes, activities and policies must be in compliance with internationally available standards. Finally, since a primary goal of the SOCIAL platform is to be technically feasible and economically viable, it was considered characteristics such as extensibility, reusability, configurability, flexibility, and maintainability. Without common and shared software architectural standards, data formats, storage systems, modules and information resources, development and integration is difficult. Not integrated software components often promote replicated data in diverse data formats and storage systems. Also, different systems, although with similar architectures, might be supported in own software modules with proprietary data formats. Moreover, although standards might be used to guarantee interoperability between different data formats the complexity of the integration made development slow and expensive, which difficult the implementation of the desired functions. To overcome these difficulties the development of the SOCIAL platform was based on a SOA approach, which presents several advantages, since it can optimize flexibility and interoperability of the components over the longer term. Furthermore, the use of an n-tier SOA allows the separation of business rules from the applications and the technologies that interpret them, which maximizes flexibility and minimizes the cost of accommodating changes in business rules, and, therefore, allows the development of specific applications without significant development effort. The generic system architecture of the SOCIAL platform was divided into three layers. The application layer comprises a set of applications to fulfil the needs of the SOCIAL platform stakeholders, including web and mobile applications that are responsible for the information exchange between the platform and its users. The business layer is responsible for all logic related to the interactions between the different applications and the data persisted in the SOCIAL platform. The data layer ensures the persistence of all information used in the remaining layers and it is divided into a set of databases, each housing specific data about a given goal. Figure 1. The FHIR gateway supports the Create, Read, Delete and Update (CRUD) data operations. Besides these operations, an advanced search is also allowed, with specific search parameters associated to each resource, in order to reduce search area and obtain more specific information. In each request a valid JSON Web Token (JWT) that follows the standard RFC 7519 [20] is required (Fig. 2). Every time that a request arrives, the JWT is validated in order to be possible the access to the requested information [21]. The previous procedure is one of the security measures in order to confine the data to undue requests. Moreover, the requests are all submitted to the authorization service so the information can be retrieved according to permissions associated to a specific role. Once again, the JWT is used to get the role and other information that is sent to authorization service that applies the access control rules and decides if the information can or cannot be achieved. According to the response of this service, the FHIR gateway is responsible for sending, as response to the initial request, the requested information that can be accessed. Considering a Read request, some fields can be omitted according to userâ€™s permissions. The other operations (i.e. Create, Update or Delete) can be permitted or denied. The authentication component is supported by the REST architecture and allows the registration of specific users in the SOCIAL platform, the assignment of the respective roles and the verification of their identities. If a user's authentication is successfully validated, the service returns a JWT. The JWT enables the secure exchange of information between parties and has the required attributes for the verification of the user's identity so that they can be authorized to access specific applications or information (Fig. 2). In particular, one of the available JWT attributes is the role that identifies the profile with which the user is currently operating. The role acts as a permission aggregator that is managed by the authorization component. A JWT should be present in all the communications between the various components of the SOCIAL platform, so each one of these components holds an encrypted private key to verify veracity and validity of the JWT they received. The FHIR resources may have security labels for three different purposes: to indicate the permissions related to information operations, such as Create or Read, to indicate what resources can be returned, and to indicate how specific information should be dealt with. Requests can also add their own security labels (e.g. break-the-glass protocol to allow a physician dealing with an emergency to access information of patient even when has not access permissions). The security labels can have different categorizations, such as confidentiality, sensitivity, compartment, integrity or handling. Integrating ABAC mechanisms with this standard is possible, since the FHIR resources are also defined by their attributes. The main purpose of the authorization service is to provide general mechanisms to control the access to the SOCIAL platform, which is an environment composed by a significant number of dispersed resources that can be accessed by a broad range of users that are distributed, both in geographical terms and in the administrative terms. The requirements initially established stated that authorization should be robust to ensure privacy, integrity and confidentiality of the information, allow the access to remote information in a friendly and transparent way, be easy to maintain and present a strong granularity in terms of the definition of different authorization levels. The XACML [16] is a standard that allows handling requests, regarding data access, using an ABAC policy language. These requests related to the access of specific resources are analyzed through a set of rules, so that a decision can be achieved. By using XACML, pre-established rules can be divided into different categories. The decision for the access request is obtained after comparing all the values of the attributes of the respective categories, between the request and the previously defined rules. Depending on how a specific decision rule was defined, a request result could be a denial or a permit (Fig. 2). Furthermore, policies and their respective rules can have different levels of detail, according to the different number of attributes needed before reaching a decision. This feature makes this standard a perfect fit for systems that handle great quantities of information, with different types of data. Finally, the logging and auditing component, as the remainder components, is based on a REST architecture, allowing the communication of the different services and applications of the SOCIAL platform via HTTP (Fig. 2). A cryptographic secure blockchain was adopted, which stores the events and the blocks (of the blockchain) in a special purpose database. Moreover, audit processes will access the stored events and blocks to determine the relevant data. For that three separate processes were considered: log insertion, log consensus and log audit. Log audit is done by direct observation of the event stream stored in the database. Existing tools such as Kibana can be used and the integrity of the data observed can be assured. The integrity of the chain can be verified anytime to 6 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 check for any inconsistencies. Since every block of the chain has a clear identification, with fingerprints of the log data, as well as time stamps of the first and last event during that time period, the hash of all the events occurred between two checkpoints can be recalculated to check if it matches the one stored in the block. The next and previous hash fields on every block can also be used to verify if the block itself has not been tampered. Figure 2. Required flow to access information from the FHIR gateway. 4. In a simple way, the following actors and respective uses cases were considered for the program offices [24]: i) assisted persons and their informal caregivers (i.e. information access, applying, registration, withdrawal, or provision 530 Marco Rosa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 164 (2019) 524â€“531 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 7 of feedback about programs and activities); ii) operational assistants (i.e. provision of information of certain activities to potential participants, enrolment and registration of participants, provision of feedback about the progress of programs and activities, and access to plans and notifications); iii) technicians of the city council (i.e. creation, allocation of human, material and economic resources, calculations of the costs, monitoring and submission of programs and activities, and access to notifications); and iv) members of the city council (i.e. approval of programs and activities, evaluation of ongoing programs and activities, and access to notifications). As a consequence of the requirementsâ€™ analysis of the programs and activities scenario, three different applications were considered: i) MySocial, a mobile and web application targeting assisted persons and their informal caregivers, aiming to provide a comprehensive but configurable set of functions; ii) SocialOperationManagement, a web application targeting care providers; and iii) SocialPlanning, a web application focused on the secondary use of information. Conclusion The authors developed a platform of services, the SOCIAL platform, which provides repositories of assisted personsâ€™ information compatible with FHIR specifications. Although FHIR is a specification for communication and interoperability, the use of the respective resources presents several advantages, namely compliance with established international standards, and information modelling using entities that are already mature and prepared to guarantee interoperability between applications. Moreover, the 8 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 FHIR specification provides a simplified abstraction of information records with normalized elements that the applications developers can understand. However, the real use of FHIR also means the need to guarantee privacy, integrity and confidentiality of the assisted personsâ€™ information. In this respect, the present study shows that it is possible to integrate FHIR implementations with complex authentication, authorization, logging and auditing mechanisms and, simultaneously, to guarantee efficiency in terms of information access by the different user-application pairs. As a consequence of the requirementsâ€™ analysis of the programs and activities scenario, three different applications were considered: i) MySocial, a mobile and web application targeting assisted persons and their informal caregivers, aiming to provide a comprehensive but configurable set of functions; ii) SocialOperationManagement, a web application targeting care providers; and iii) SocialPlanning, a web application focused on the secondary use of information. These applications manage different types of information, such as, for example, demographic information (e.g. name, date of birth, gender, marital status, profession, schooling, household, nationality, identification document, address, telephone or email), personal factors (e.g. physical conditions, lifestyles, habits, facing problems skills, social background, or past and present life events), or data that characterize specific programs, activities, situations or events. To validate the proposed solution a test scenario was created consisting of a random number of users (between 100 and 200 users) that for 60 minutes randomly accessed three concurrent applications (i.e. MySocial, SocialOperationManagement and SocialPlanning). This test scenario was created to answer the following questions: â€¢ For each user profile, what is the average delay time between a platform access with a token and the reception of the indication of all the operations that the specific profile can perform? â€¢ What is the average delay time between a request to access a specific packet of information stored in the FHIR gateway and the complete reception of all the information by the requesting application? Table 1 present the average delay time obtained for each profile when performing a platform access with a token (i.e. to execute the flow from â€˜platform access with tokenâ€™ until â€˜show authorized menusâ€™ tabsâ€™ as presented in Fig. 2). As it can be seen the average time varied from 111.2 ms (i.e. assisted persons) to 120.4 ms (i.e. members of the city council), due to the different number and type of operations that each profile can perform. In turn, in what concerns the second question, the delay time for accessing a 368 kb packet containing a list of available programs (i.e. the flow from â€˜CRUD operationâ€™ until â€˜show resultsâ€™ as presented in Fig. 2) varied from 257.2 ms and 600.7 ms and assumed an average value of 458.9 ms. The results show that even with large quantities of events in short periods of time, the SOCIAL platform can successful manage the access of the different user-application pairs. Therefore, the proposed solution is efficient in terms of information accessing, which means that it can support an application ecosystem. Table 1. Average delay time obtained for each profile. Conclusion The authors developed a platform of services, the SOCIAL platform, which provides repositories of assisted personsâ€™ information compatible with FHIR specifications. Although FHIR is a specification for communication and interoperability, the use of the respective resources presents several advantages, namely compliance with established international standards, and information modelling using entities that are already mature and prepared to guarantee interoperability between applications. Moreover, the 8 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 FHIR specification provides a simplified abstraction of information records with normalized elements that the applications developers can understand. However, the real use of FHIR also means the need to guarantee privacy, integrity and confidentiality of the assisted personsâ€™ information. In this respect, the present study shows that it is possible to integrate FHIR implementations with complex authentication, authorization, logging and auditing mechanisms and, simultaneously, to guarantee efficiency in terms of information access by the different user-application pairs.
