doc_title: Smart Cities and Public Health: A Systematic Review
doc_abstract: © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.Objectives - The study reported in this article aimed to identify: i) the most relevant smart cities' applications with impact in public health; ii) the types of technologies being used; and iii) the maturity level of the applications being reported. Methods - A systematic review was performed based on a search of the literature. Results - A total of 19 articles were retrieved. The articles report applications to support surveillance of populations and environmental conditions and to promote healthy lifestyles. Conclusion - Although relevant arguments were made regarding the importance of smart cities' infrastructures to support public health, most of the articles report applications in an early stage of development.

Introduction Smart cities can be seen as cities capable of collecting and analyzing vast quantities of data, through low-cost sensors, data-actuated devices and wireless communication networks [1]. These data are collected and analyzed to promote automate and intelligent processes (e.g. advanced data analytic), to improve the quality of the available services and to promote the emergence of new ones. Trencher and Karvonen [11] present a real-world case study on the Japanese smart city of Kashiwanoha, which follows three main approaches: monitoring devices (e.g. wearable activity sensor, pedometer or scales) to capture continuous lifestyle data, provision of educational initiatives concentrated in walking, diet, and socializing, and enticement for behavioral change, which includes gamification based on the collected lifestyle data. The study found that citizens were well engaged in using these three approaches and were observed concrete changes in their behavior towards a healthier lifestyle. In turn, Yu et al. [12] propose an intelligent farm relaxation concept and develop the architecture of an intelligent farm management system based on internet of things technology. Finally, Fran Casino et al. [13] present a context-aware recommender system that offers personalized recommendations of exercise routes to people according to their medical condition and real-time information from a smart city. [14] propose a data analytic system to predict and reduce the impact of traffic accidents and uncover relevant patterns followed by accidents. The system is trained with past data using a decision tree method. The data set to test the system was received by the office of Traffic Commissioner at Bangalore and integrated information such as the type of accidents, light conditions, severity, speed zone, and alcohol consumptions. With this implementation, it was possible, among other results, to lighten hidden causes for the accidents, as well as to identify primary causes. The authors emphasize the advantages in improving the collection and analysis of additional data, namely using sensors inside the vehicles or the global positioning system (GPS). Some future applications are mentioned, such as timely report of information to police, hospitals and emergency services, implementation of protective measure to ensure road-safety of older adults and school children, and design of policies to guarantee more road-safety. Discussion and Conclusion Only one article [11] reports a real-world trial involving the population of a smart city. All the remained 18 articles classified as public health and analyzed in this review report applications in an early stage of development. However, it must be emphasized that all the articles report and discuss important topics and tools with significant future applications in the context of smart cities. After this revision, it is also possible to state that, in the case of public health, relevant arguments were made regarding the importance of smart citiesâ€™ infrastructures. Concerning the first research question (i.e. the most relevant smart citiesâ€™ applications with impact in public health), we may conclude that there is a concern to develop smart citiesâ€™ applications to support surveillance of the populations and the environment. The types of this surveillance are diverse and include surveillance of traffic accidents [14], environmental conditions [15, 16], electromagnetic radiation [9], health conditions of older adults [17, 18], emotions [10, 19-23], epidemics [24, 25], level of fitness activity [26] and food quality [27]. Furthermore, three articles deal with the promotion of healthy lifestyles [11, 12, 13]. It should be pointed out that a significant number of articles (i.e. [10, 19-23]) deal with population emotions surveillance. The studies reported by these articles use different kind of applications (e.g. Twitter, Flickr, Instagram, Facebook, smartphone apps or web-portals) to detect relevant affective states of the individuals, which can be aggregated and correlated to objective measurements (e.g. socio-demographic statistics, questionnaires, data retrieved from biometric sensors, or urban geography areas and features). These results show that the implementation of smart cities can have impact in public health (i.e. disease prevention and health promotions) and, therefore, are in line with current concerns of the developed countries [28]. With respect to the technologies being used (i.e. the second research question), the use of social networks (e.g. [21- 23]) is reported in various articles. Also, cloud computing is being used to store relevant data and different technologies, including natural languages processing [21], are being used to process these data. In terms of data acquisition, the included articles report the use of a wide range of sensors (e.g. sensors inside vehicles [14], photo voltaic sensors [16], gas sensors [27] or biometric sensors [11, 20, 21, 24, 26]). These sensors can acquire relevant environmental or individualsâ€™ data. It should be noted that in one specific study [15], environmental data is correlated to genetic information of individuals to evaluate how their genetics are performing and interacting with their environment in a city. Finally, concerning the third research question (i.e. the maturity level of the applications being reported), all the studies except one are in an early stage of development. Considering the research methods that were used, different approaches were considered: prototypes were developed to demonstrate the feasibility of the concepts [13, 14, 16, 20, 21, 27], prototypes were implemented and used to evaluate its effectiveness for a given use case [10, 18, 25], and architectures were defined [12, 24, 26]. Moreover, two articles are project descriptions [15, 17], one is a methodological approach [23], one is an assessment of existing methods [22] and another one [19] illustrates a few examples of applications that would benefit from the availability of affective data. Only one article [11] presents a real-world trial on a Japanese smart city. However, it is difficult to foresee its portability to other cities since data- driven approaches to health management risk bumping against social norms. Therefore, this systematic review of the literature shows that the articles report solutions still far from consolidated solutions and most of them do not report evidence about the evaluation of the applications in real environments neither about their evaluation in the context of smart cities. After this revision it is also possible to state that, in the case of public health, relevant arguments were made regarding the importance of smart citiesâ€™ infrastructures in order to enhance the potential of the described solutions. Moreover, in some cases, the authors tried to redefine the role of smart applications with impact in the public health in the cities of the future. Nevertheless, it is evident the lack of robust evaluation trials, since most of the solutions being reported are proof of concepts prototypes. It is also evident that the implementation of smart cities is still in an early stage and is still not largely imbued within public health domain. Although the authors tried, in methodological terms, to guarantee that the review selection and the data extraction were rigorous, it should be acknowledged that this study has limitations, namely the dependency on the keywords and the selected databases and the fact that both grey literature and publications written in other languages than English were excluded. 8 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 References 1. doc_title: Analysis of the Data Consistency of Medical Imaging Information Systems: An Exploratory Study
doc_abstract: © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.In the context of medical imaging, a considerable amount of data is created on daily basis, which are produced and managed by multiple medical imaging and information systems. The professional and department performance, as well as the respective characterization, are supported by these data, which makes their quality a critical aspect to take into account. The work developed had the objective of analysing the existence of nonconformities related to the consistency of the Radiology Information Systems (RIS) and Picture and Communication System (PACS) databases, as well as their precision, accuracy, integrity and associated risks for the healthcare practice. Data belonging to 1068 computed radiography studies were analysed and ten nonconformities were identified, related to the patient name, patient age, patient date of birth, patient gender, study date, study time, institution identification, radiologist identification, number of radiographic projections performed, and billing code. The work carried out allowed identifying some lack of data quality, sometimes evidenced in the absence of consistency, precision, accuracy and integrity.

Introduction The development of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT), and their use in clinical contexts made it possible to acquire and integrate patientsâ€™ data resulting from multiple episodes/procedures. These data are acquired and managed by different information systems, namely electronic health records [1], with different functional, technological and architectural perspectives [2]. The use of ICT promotes improved healthcare delivery. This is particularly evident in developing countries where the implementation of clinical information systems improves communication between institutions, helps the organization and management of medicines, and allows monitoring and detecting patients who can abandon treatment, among other contributions [3]. For several decades now, the growing complexity and scope of ICT in clinical settings has been evident in different areas of healthcare provision, namely in the area of medical imaging, allowing the aggregation and availability of data to different stakeholders, which might be internal or external to the organizations [4]. Regarding medical imaging professionals, they access in a daily basis to multiple information systems, such as Hospital Information Systems (HIS), Radiology Information Systems (RIS) and Picture Archiving and Communication Systems (PACS). The networking of these systems promotes the collection, analysis, dissemination and archiving of patientâ€™s clinical information and also information related to the actors involved in the provision of healthcare over the time [5]. Concerning the requests for examinations managed by RIS, a critical process for carrying out medical imaging studies [6] that requires data to be shared with PACS databases, some authors have identified lack of data quality [7][8] which may undermine the provision of healthcare [9]. The healthcare provision as well as the professional and department performance characterization are supported by these data, which makes their quality a critical aspect to consider. Therefore, the exploratory study being reported aimed to find out nonconformities related to the consistency of RIS and PACS databases, in terms of their integrity, precision and accuracy, as well as their risks for the clinical practice. 2. Background The development, adoption, and implementation of new technological resources in a clinical context can promote better access to health data, with the potential to reduce attendance errors, increase collaboration between clinicians and improve communication between clinicians and patients, if adequate strategies are implemented to allow the exchange of correct and timely clinical data among the different stakeholders [3][11]. Usually, in a clinical context, the installed information systems were developed and are supported by different manufacturers and software vendors [12]. Consequently, the exchange of data often results in fragmented or even duplicate versions and, frequently, health institutions have the same data stored under different formats in different systems. This means that extra complexity is required to maintain consistency between different databases [13]. The quality of the clinical data has been object of study over the years, mainly due to the need to characterize the procedures supported by these data. For instance, Botsis et al. [10] found inconsistency, inaccuracy and lack of data in electronic health records databases. Moreover, Cruz Correia et al. [14] identified that 94.2% of all HL7 message traffic generated by healthcare institution presented nonconformities that jeopardized their quality, being the concept of quality considered as "suitability for use" (i.e. in accordance with the objectives of the messagesâ€™ use). According to Muller and Freytag, [17] nonconformities detected in clinical data can be semantic (e.g. integrity constraint violations or contradictions), syntactical (e.g. lexical errors, domain format errors or irregularities), and coverage (e.g. missing values or tuples anomalies) nonconformities. Botsis et al. [10] found that data inconsistencies result from two reasons: i) fragmentation caused by care records performed at different healthcare facilities; and ii) lack of contextual information caused by poor medical documentation. Since the quality of the data may be dependent on several factors, it can be analysed according to different dimensions. In particular, the data should be relevant, timely, accurate, complete, sufficiently detailed and consistent (i.e. appropriately represented), and should retain contextual information [15][16]. [10] found inconsistency, inaccuracy and lack of data in electronic health records databases. Moreover, Cruz Correia et al. [14] identified that 94.2% of all HL7 message traffic generated by healthcare institution presented nonconformities that jeopardized their quality, being the concept of quality considered as "suitability for use" (i.e. in accordance with the objectives of the messagesâ€™ use). According to Muller and Freytag, [17] nonconformities detected in clinical data can be semantic (e.g. integrity constraint violations or contradictions), syntactical (e.g. lexical errors, domain format errors or irregularities), and coverage (e.g. missing values or tuples anomalies) nonconformities. [10] found that data inconsistencies result from two reasons: i) fragmentation caused by care records performed at different healthcare facilities; and ii) lack of contextual information caused by poor medical documentation. In particular, the data should be relevant, timely, accurate, complete, sufficiently detailed and consistent (i.e. appropriately represented), and should retain contextual information [15][16]. Therefore, some studies 510 Joana Almeida et al. / Procedia Computer Science 164 (2019) 508â€“515 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 3 were focused on the analysis of data quality in different dimensions in order to perform evaluations and comparisons, so that a set of guidelines were developed and proposed to consistently report and compare the results related to clinical data quality [10][18][19]. Moreover, it is necessary to ensure that data are consistent independently of being stored in multiple databases [20]. According to Mphatswe et al. [21], clinicians lifelong training and periodic data reviews and audits are processes that can promote the improvement of data quality. In the scope of medical imaging, data nonconformities are related to incorrect patientsâ€™ data records or studiesâ€™ requests, which makes evident the importance of tools to allow the reconciliation of patientsâ€™ data [22]. On the other hand, the existence of errors or non-compliance in the data registered in RIS and PACS databases often implies to process images and to correct the records in order to guarantee the right record of the patients and respective episodes [23]. In this context, Nissen-Meyer et al. [20] developed a tool to verify the correctness of a set of identification criteria associated with essential HIS, RIS and PACS data. In the specific case of data reconciliation of RIS and PACS databases, Nitrosi et al. [27] highlighted four types of errors, each one with a respective degree of severity: i) incorrect fusion of different data regarding the same patient (moderate risk); ii) incorrect linking of an image or study to an episode or patient (high risk); iii) incorrect assignment of images or study to an event of the same patient (high risk); and iv) incorrect identification of projection/laterality (high risk). 3. Material and Methods The data on computed radiography studies (i.e. â€œChest - two projectionsâ€�, â€œAbdomen - one projectionâ€� and â€œBilateral - two projectionsâ€�) performed for one month in a medium-sized hospital were analysed. The choice of these type of studies was based on the fact that they are among the most performed at National [28] and European levels [29]. The research study was authorized by the administration board and the ethics committee of the involved hospital, being assured that the data collected would be treated in a way that would maintain the confidentiality and privacy of the patients as well as of all those that performed and analysed the imaging studies. Moreover, the experimental work was developed in three phases. During phase one the RIS and PACS databases were analysed in order to collect information about existing fields and respective filling levels related to patients and requested studies. In turn, during phase two the collected information was structured to allow a comparative analysis of RIS and PACS databases fields (i.e. an intra-field and inter-field analysis). Finally, during phase three it was identified and characterized the existing nonconformities between RIS and PACS database data. Discussion 5.1. Accuracy, Precision and Integrity Deficits Nonconformities were identified in which, although there is consistency between the data from RIS and PACS databases, deficits related to the precision, accuracy and integrity dimensions were present (Table 4). The patient name data field is always populated in both databases. However, it was possible to identify situations in which for the same study and patient, the patient name was not the same in both databases (NC1). For example, in several situations the complete name of the patient was stored in the PACS database, while in the RIS database the name was incomplete, and vice-versa. This nonconformity was detected in about 0.5% of the "Chest - two projections" studies and 1.2% of the "Abdomen - one projection" studies. One possible explanation might be that manual insertion of patientsâ€™ data occurred when the information system was not accessible such, as, for example, in cases of urgency or lack of connection between information systems. This nonconformity can be considered as high risk, since the physician when using the patient name to query the information system, which is a very common practice, might select the wrong patient. Regarding the institution identification nonconformity (NC7), accuracy and precision deficits were identified (e.g. empty fields or fields with different contents appearing in the RIS database when compared to the PACS database) in 6.5% of the chest studies, and in residual percentages for the other studies. The same happens with nonconformities related to the identification of the radiologist who executes or validates the study (NC8). A high percentage of this type of nonconformities is present in the Abdomen studies (97.0%). Although the respective field exist in the PACS database, it was not populated, which means that it was not possible to compare the information stored in the databases of the two information systems. Similar situations were also identified in other studies when analysing medical image repositories [24]. When comparing the Radiologist field with the Operator field (both belonging to the RIS database), sometimes it was present the identification of the technician performing the procedure. The nonconformity of the both fields are considered to have medium risk since they do not endanger the health condition of the patients. However, in situations that is necessary to contact the technicians responsible for performing the studies, important information may be incorrect. Regarding the number of projections made and stored in the PACS archives (NC9), the analysis fell into two distinct but directly linked fields. The Number of study images field belonging to the PACS database was compared with the Description of the study field belonging to the RIS database. In 51.0% of the "Chest - two projections" studies, a difference was notice between the number of stored images and the two projections that should be a part of the study. This percentage is higher (56.4%) in the "Bilateral Hips - two projections" studies. This can result from an incorrect request or change of procedures because of the characteristics of the patients. This nonconformity was considered to be of medium risk, however, it may eventually have repercussions when analysing the productivity of the medical imaging department, since this analysis is usually based on the data present in the RIS database and not on the data of the PACS database, irrespective of being the latter one the information system that effectively reports the procedures that were performed. Concerning NC10, related to the coding of the procedures for later billing (Billing code field of the RIS database), once more it was not identified data consistency problems. However, it was identified deficits of accuracy and precision when compared to the field Number of study images of the PACS database. For example, in one situation, although a "Chest - two projections" study should have two images, the corresponding Billing code correspond to a study "Chest PA", which has only one projection. This type of nonconformity was detected in about 80.0% of the "Chest two projections" studies, in 94.9% of the "Bilateral Hips - two projections" studies and in 82.8% of the "Abdomen - one projection" studies. This type of nonconformity can be considered to have a medium risk because it has no severe consequences for the patients. 5.2. doc_title: A systematic review of smart cities' applications to support active ageing
doc_abstract: © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.Objectives-This study aimed to identify: (i) relevant smart city applications to promote active ageing; (ii) types of technologies being used; and (iii) maturity levels of the applications being reported. Methods-A systematic review was performed based on a search of the literature. Results-A total of 13 articles were retrieved. These studies report smart cities' applications to promote active ageing, using different types of sensing devices. Conclusion-Most of the included articles are either of descriptive and conceptual nature or in an early stage of development, which means that there is still a lack of concreteness.

Introduction During the ageing process, a significant number of role transitions occur, and these transitions vary from individual to individual [1,2]. As a consequence, there are impacts on the psychological well-being of the older adults and, therefore, it is important for them to find and foster new parallel roles, functioning at the same level as the previous, in order to maintain the quality, frequency and purpose of interactions with others. In this context, the active ageing concept has an increasing importance [3,4]. Active aging aims the maintenance of patterns of activities and values typical of middle age and can be understand as a process of optimizing opportunities for social participation, health conditions, and the safety of the individuals, in order to promote their quality of life as they age [5,6]. Therefore, it must consider not only the characteristics of the older adults, but also environmental factors that can act as barriers or facilitators [7]. In this regard, well-designed technological solutions can act as facilitators. Many researchers aimed to develop new services based on Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) to provide support for active ageing. For instance, numerous Ambient Assisted Living (AAL) applications have been built to enable older adults to achieve their full potential in terms of physical, social, and mental well-being [8]. Therefore, it is important to systematize current evidence related to the impact of new technological applications and related services in terms of active ageing. Concretely, the systematic review reported in this article aimed to identify relevant applications supported in smart cities infrastructure that can promote the participation and inclusion of older adults in the community as full rights citizens. This is useful to inform smart citiesâ€™ stakeholders about state-of-the-art solutions with impact in active ageing and to identify gaps of the current research. 2. Methods For the specific objective of the systematic review reported by this article the following research questions were formulated: ï‚· RQ1 - What are the relevant smart city applications to promote active ageing? ï‚· RQ2 - What are the types of technologies being used? ï‚· RQ3 - What are the maturity levels of the applications being reported? Boolean queries were prepared to include all the articles published before December 31, 2017 that have in their titles, abstracts or keywords at least one of the following expressions: â€˜Smart Cityâ€™, â€˜Smart Citiesâ€™ â€˜Smartcityâ€™, â€˜Smartcitiesâ€™, â€˜Smart-cityâ€� or â€˜Smart-citiesâ€™. The resources considered to be searched were two general databases, Web of Science and Scopus, and one specific technological database, IEEE Xplore. The literature search was performed on January 2018. As inclusion criteria, the authors aimed to include all the articles that report evidence of explicit use of applications requiring smart citiesâ€™ infrastructures to promote active ageing. Considering the exclusion criteria, the authors aimed to exclude all the articles not published in English, without abstract or without access to full text. Furthermore, the authors also aimed to exclude all the articles that report overviews, reviews and applications that do not explicitly require smart citiesâ€™ infrastructures, or that were not relevant for the specific aim of this study. After the removal of duplicates and articles without abstract, the analysis of the remainder articles was performed according the following steps: ï‚· First, the authors assessed all abstracts for relevance and those clearly outside the scope of the present systematic review were removed. ï‚· Then, the abstracts of the retrieved articles were assessed to verify if they were related to smart living, which includes health conditions. Those articles reporting studies not related to smart living were excluded. ï‚· Afterwards, the abstracts of the remaining articles were assessed according to the outlined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Considering these remainder 13 articles, ten were published in conference proceedings and only three were published in scientific journals [17-19]. [20] proposed an application that integrates WiFi networks deployed in rural areas to locate older adults in their homes and in specific nearby areas which they commonly frequent. An intelligent application with personalized multimedia content was used to control the locations. This was done through a topbox which was connected to a television and offers continuous monitoring of the individuals. The application was tested in a small locality in the province of Salamanca, Spain, being the tracking application activated in four homes equipped with a topbox set and a tracking tag in each one. The authors concluded that the developed application makes it easy to monitor older adults at a low cost since it is not necessary to install complex hardware, and because the hardware installed has other uses beyond monitoring. Still, regarding the monitoring application, it would be necessary to test it with more real data and load the case memory in the real anomalous cases in order to better analyze its functioning. In turn, Wireless Body Area Networks (WBAN) were used to communicate data resulting from the gathering of physiological parameters. The assessment of the location performance was done through a set of experimental simulations using the MATLAB environment. The same argument is followed in [22], which aims to present an architecture for a service to locate older adults. This pilot had adopted a user centric iterative design approach with 35 care receivers actively involved in all phases of the project to validate the data detection and intervention services. Finally, from the remainder 19 articles, six articles were excluded during the full text review due to the following reasons: (i) one article is an overview [11]; (ii) one article was excluded because it was not possible to access the respective full text [12]; (iii) one article reports the development of applications that do not require smart city infrastructures [13]; (iv) one article presents a critical analysis of implementation the concept of smart city based on six indicators, namely smart people, smart economy, smart environment, smart government, smart living and smart mobility [14]; (v) one article presents a review of other works about the relation between unhealthy lifestyles and built environments, including smart cities [15]; and (vi) one article reports a study not directly related to smart city but to smart farming. The association to smart city was that farm relaxation is a type of city tourism [16]. Considering these remainder 13 articles, ten were published in conference proceedings and only three were published in scientific journals [17-19]. Based on their analysis, the following classes were considered: (i) monitoring applications; (ii) applications to support activities and participation; (iii) promotion of healthy lifestyles; and (iv) community platforms. 3.1. Monitoring Applications Within the scope of applications to monitor older adults, five articles [20-24] were considered. Villarrubia et al. [20] proposed an application that integrates WiFi networks deployed in rural areas to locate older adults in their homes and in specific nearby areas which they commonly frequent. An intelligent application with personalized multimedia content was used to control the locations. This was done through a topbox which was connected to a television and offers continuous monitoring of the individuals. The application was tested in a small locality in the province of Salamanca, Spain, being the tracking application activated in four homes equipped with a topbox set and a tracking tag in each one. The authors concluded that the developed application makes it easy to monitor older adults at a low cost since it is not necessary to install complex hardware, and because the hardware installed has other uses beyond monitoring. Still, regarding the monitoring application, it would be necessary to test it with more real data and load the case memory in the real anomalous cases in order to better analyze its functioning. Concerning [21], the final aim was to ensure a localization service for older adults that should be provided in time and when it is necessary, namely when older adults are outside (i.e., to enable the city to provide an outside individualsâ€™ monitoring while promoting their ability to perform leisure activities). The authors took advantage of the Internet of Things (IoT) paradigm for collecting heterogeneous data that are broadcast in the city. In turn, Wireless Body Area Networks (WBAN) were used to communicate data resulting from the gathering of physiological parameters. The assessment of the location performance was done through a set of experimental simulations using the MATLAB environment. The same argument is followed in [22], which aims to present an architecture for a service to locate older adults. Through highlighting the importance of integrating the social resources of citizens into the core of what a smart city is, the ideas presented in [23] and [24], which take part of the same project (City4Age), use technologies to collect data related to older adults. Bryant et al. [23] provided a description of the first phase of the Birmingham City4Age. This pilot had adopted a user centric iterative design approach with 35 care receivers actively involved in all phases of the project to validate the data detection and intervention services. For that it was used advances in wearables, smart phones and sensors to collect and process vast amounts of data in real time to enhance and build a more comprehensive and predictive 310 Nelson Rocha et al. / Procedia Computer Science 160 (2019) 306â€“313 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 5 picture of individualsâ€™ wellbeing and health, which aims to sustain better health outcomes and deliver early interventions to anticipate needs. Applications to Support Activities and Participation Three articles are focused on technologies supporting older adultsâ€™ activities and participation [17,25,26]. Zschippig & Kluss [17] present guidelines for the implementation of intelligent AAL gardens, raising awareness that gardening is a leisure activity which should be supported through ICT, as it is popular for older adults. The rationale is that, since the garden is to be part of the AAL home and not a separate application, features known from existing AAL applications, such as activity recognition, fall detection or health monitoring, should be expanded into the outdoor areas of the garden. The concept was presented only in a descriptive manner, and the authors concluded that the fully automated, unsupervised maintenance of the comprehensive AAL garden is likely to require more research efforts in the field of robotics and socio-technological systems to achieve practical and desirable applications. In turn, Lopez-de-Ipina et al. [25] propose a proof of concept platform for ambient assisted cities able to sense the city activities in order to promote the creation of an ecosystem of user-centric apps to help citizens, taking into account their disabilities, in their daily activities. This platform was developed within a research project, and the report is a work-in-progress and an opportunity for the authors to explain how are bring together the achievements of earlier works. With respect to [26], the idea was to highlight the potential of technology in public urban areas to raise awareness. According to the authors, smart urban objects are elements of the urban environment (e.g., posts, bulletin boards or benches), which might be connected to a digital information space to allow for implicit or explicit interaction with the individuals. By pondering theoretically on the subject, the authors argued that there is still a major challenge for research to determine how to design human computer interaction for walk-up-and-use in public spaces. 3.3. Promotion of Healthy Lifestyles Three articles are focused the promotion of healthy lifestyles [18,19,27]. Trencher & Karvonen [18] present a real-world case study on the Japanese smart city of Kashiwanoha, which follows three main approaches: (i) monitoring devices (e.g., wearable activity sensors, pedometers or scales) to capture continuous lifestyle data; (ii) provision of educational initiatives concentrated in walking, diet, and socializing; and (iii) enticement for behavioral change, including gamification based on the collected lifestyle data. An open-door policy allowed for free use by out-of-town residents and there were several users who lived in neighboring cities. Moreover, although the facility was for all ages, about two-thirds of the regulars were over 60 years old. The study found that citizens were well engaged in using these three approaches and were observed concrete changes in their behavior towards a healthier lifestyle. In [19] is reported a context-aware recommender application that offers personalized recommendations of exercise routes to individuals according to their medical condition and real-time information from a smart city. The application has predefined routes and recommends the best route based on a memory-based method that employs neighborhood search (to determine groups of similar individuals) and on information acquired from the smart city infrastructure such as air quality, ultraviolet radiation, wind speed, temperature, or precipitation. The individuals can then select the best course according to their profile (e.g., age, effort or distance) and can inform the application about unexpected situations that could affect other users. Moreover, they can also propose new routes. The 6 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 application was configured for two cities and first tested with simulated users which age distribution and medical statistics followed the reports of the World Health Organization and the World Heart Federation. Later, a real trial was conducted with 20 individuals for one city and it was found that the quality of the recommendations was like the one obtained by simulation. Stibe et al. [27] introduced the concept of persuasive cities by presenting an ecosystem for the future of cities. They proposed a strategy that was also included in [18], the behavioral change with gamification. Therefore, the article explains how to define behavior change and reports tools for the social engineering of persuasive cities. Although the strategy does not imply having a smart city to be applied, from the discussion and from the examples is inferred that a smart city is a key enabler of such approach in a city context. The authors advance possible scenarios were their concept could be used, such as reducing sedentary behavior, increasing water conservation, and promoting walking. However, for testing its effectiveness in the long run, robust evidence is required. 3.4. Community Platforms Two articles address the topic of older adultsâ€™ community platforms [28,29]. The aim of [28] was to expand the current visions of smart cities for older adults by building along three main dimensions: technology, agency and community. Following a case study approach, the authors developed a web- based community platform to offer three types of services related with mutual help, local events and local businesses. Over 100 active and independent individuals (aged 60-81) were involved in two case studies of age- friendly smart communities, which ranged from designing a mutual help service to co-creating routes of geo-located information about different topics. In this study, conducted in Ã€gora, Barcelona, Spain, urban technologies were dynamically integrated within the ecosystem of existing technologies and communication practices and acted as triggers of new community behaviors. The authors concluded by emphasizing the importance of looking at creative use when pursuing innovation in smart cities. With respect to [29], the authors focused on an intergenerational database and on the development of a prototype for mobile devices to allow collaborative creation of walking routes based on georeferenced points of interest. Providing the theoretical and methodological background of the project Viseu InterAge Stories (VIAS), which was not yet implemented, the idea was to follow a participatory design method, involving ethnographic and action research studies, including workshops with local participants of different generations. Therefore, intergenerational activities were explored, namely by mapping the points of interest with books value and associated physical activity. According the expected path, the authors anticipated developing a mobile application able to promote collaborative interaction practices among different generations. 4. Moreover, algorithms are proposed to process these data [19]. Additionally, one articles report the use of social media [28]. Finally in what concerns the third research question (i. e. maturity level of the applications being reported), three articles [17,26,29] propose concepts for further development, two articles, [23,24], are related to the same project (City4Age project) and report ongoing activities to requirements elicitation using interactive design approach, two 312 Nelson Rocha et al. / Procedia Computer Science 160 (2019) 306â€“313 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 7 articles purpose theoretical models that were validated using simulation techniques [19,21], one article defines an architecture [22], two articles present prototypes that were developed to demonstrate the feasibility of the concepts [25,27] and three articles report prototypes that were assessed by real users [18,20,28]. It is worthwhile to mention that only three articles refer concerns related to accessibility [17,24,25] and, surprisingly, only in one article, [29], the authors refer the intention to perform usability assessment of the applications being developed. This seems to be common to other areas [31]. To conclude, most of the 13 included articles reporting smart citiesâ€™ applications to promote active ageing are either of descriptive and conceptual nature or in an early stage of development. Moreover, most of the included references published in conference proceedings. As an additional remark, many of the reported studies are part of funded projects. As such, the articles, not only appear to be an opportunity to broadcast the projects, but as most of the studies are still ongoing, there is still a lack of concreteness and, accordingly, results are scarce. Another aspect that deserves attention is the fact that the number of references resulting is not very representative within the total of articles related to smart cities. On the other hand, the implementation of smart cities is still not largely imbued within the healthy and active ageing domain, but this symbiosis should be explored. Finally, though many articles focusing on smart cities tend generally to describe technological solutions, within the topic under study there are several articles that underline the importance of going beyond technological determinisms and, accordingly, consider the citizensâ€™ perspectives. In other words, technologies should respond to user needs and not the other way around. As such, in these papers, data was collected through the application of questionnaires in order to develop solutions that fit user needs. In some cases, however, technology was used to collect data and/or promote usersâ€™ interaction during the process. An example is the use of technological platforms integrating various sources of information. Still, within this set of articles there seems to be a scarce concern in verifying the effectiveness of the solutions designed to fit the usersâ€™ perspectives. It is always possible to point out limitations about both the chosen keywords and the databases that were used in the research. Moreover, since most articles were published in conference proceedings, it should be borne in mind that, since there are many non-indexed conferences, there will certainly be similar articles that have not been included. It should also be noted that the grey literature was not considered in this review and that this can be seen as a gap of some significance, since it is assumed that there are many local field projects that are not published in scientific articles, but which will be reported in limited announcements (e.g., bulletins from city councils). In despite of these limitations, in methodological terms, the authors tried to guarantee that the review selection and the data extraction were rigorous, so that the results are relevant to identify applications supported in smart cities infrastructure that can promote active ageing. doc_title: A platform of services to support community-dwelling older adults integrating fhir and complex security mechanisms
doc_abstract: © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.The paper presents the core services (i.e., information persistence, authentication, authorization, logging and auditing) of the Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) platform, a platform aiming to support community-dwelling older adults. In addition to the description of the services' implementation, using state of the art technological solutions (e.g., Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources, eXtensible Access Control Markup Language or blockchain), the paper also presents the assessment of their performance considering an application scenario related to local authorities.

Introduction The authors were involved in the development of a platform of services, the Social Cooperation for Integrated Assisted Living (SOCIAL) platform, which intends to provide core components that are required to introduce a range of coherent applications to support community-dwelling older adults [1,2]. These applications should ensure integrated, consistent and cross-cutting view of the information, and efficient communication mechanisms, in order to contribute to care integration, empowerment of older adults and their informal caregivers, and strengthen of social care institutions. The study reported by the present paper was focused on the core components of the SOCIAL platform, namely the services related to information persistence, authentication, authorization, logging and auditing. In addition to the description of the respective implementation, the paper also presents their assessment, which was based on an application scenario related to a social support office of a Portuguese municipality. The following sections present the motivation of the research work, the proposed technological solution, the respective assessment and a conclusion. 2. Background The ageing of the population and the consequent increase in resource consumption in the age group over 65 requires efficiency and effectiveness of care provision. Particularly, there is a need to evolve from a care provision predominantly focused on illness over a socially oriented care with a higher attention to quality of life and social support [3]. This concern is evident in the public policies of the last years in many countries, notably in European Union countries [4,5]. Regardless of the specific characteristics of each country, community care is accepted as an important component in the continuity and integration of care, a key issue for current care delivery systems to be able to respond and adjust to changing realities [4-9]. When looking at what people, namely older adults, want from care delivered in their homes, several issues emerge, such as: to consider the personsâ€™ needs together in a holistic and integrated way; to ensure that care is consistent and reliable; or to ensure that people are able to express their preferences, views and feelings and to understand their choices about local care options, including quality and financial issues [6]. Moreover, another important issue is the possibility to support older adults to do things themselves, including contribution to their local community [6]. To guarantee the provision of care services in the community, there are different types of interacting entities, namely public and private health care institutions, institutions providing social care services, formal and informal caregivers (e.g., relatives, friends, neighbors, volunteers or colleagues), life assistance providers (e.g., cleaning, transportation or delivering goods at home) or providers addressing less tangible values such as participation (e.g., to facilitate social, religious, civic and political participation). Moreover, there are supportive stakeholders, including authorities and supporters dealing with socio-economical and legal context of care provision, whose involvement is fundamental to ensure funding and to safeguard the legal framework in which service provision can reach the target public. In this respect, in many countries local authorities are one of the resources for the first contact with the population and have the responsibility to lead and supervise the provision of the care in the community [10-13]. Currently, in order to maximize care provision in terms of quality, access, effectiveness, efficiency and user satisfaction, attention is focused in a rapidly expanding of digital applications [6]. Digital technology can be used for prevention, to promote the engagement between different levels or care (e.g., primary and secondary care, or health and social care), to support paid and unpaid care providers, or to improve productivity and quality by enabling new ways of working and facilitating information flow and, therefore, promoting more integrated and responsive services. Different groups of technologies, although focused in specific aspects, can contribute for the care in the community, so that older adults might live safely, independently, autonomously, and comfortably in their own residences, but with the necessary support services to their changing needs [14], including those resulting from multiple impairments (e.g., declines in cognitive and functional abilities) [15, 16]. When looking at what people, namely older adults, want from care delivered in their homes, several issues emerge, such as: to consider the personsâ€™ needs together in a holistic and integrated way; to ensure that care is consistent and reliable; or to ensure that people are able to express their preferences, views and feelings and to understand their choices about local care options, including quality and financial issues [6]. Moreover, another important issue is the possibility to support older adults to do things themselves, including contribution to their local community [6]. To guarantee the provision of care services in the community, there are different types of interacting entities, namely public and private health care institutions, institutions providing social care services, formal and informal caregivers (e.g., relatives, friends, neighbors, volunteers or colleagues), life assistance providers (e.g., cleaning, transportation or delivering goods at home) or providers addressing less tangible values such as participation (e.g., to facilitate social, religious, civic and political participation). Moreover, there are supportive stakeholders, including authorities and supporters dealing with socio-economical and legal context of care provision, whose involvement is fundamental to ensure funding and to safeguard the legal framework in which service provision can reach the target public. In this respect, in many countries local authorities are one of the resources for the first contact with the population and have the responsibility to lead and supervise the provision of the care in the community [10-13]. Regardless of the role they play on the platform, their demographic information should be registered. Moreover, in the case of formal care providers, they may belong to a given institution (e.g., a health care or a social care institution, or even a City Council or a Borough Council). The Person FHIR resource might be associated to several instantiations belonging to the same user, allowing the different roles that each user can assume within the platform. In the case of users assuming the role of care provider, they can be characterized by the following FHIR resources: Practitioner (i.e., a person who is directly or indirectly involved in the provisioning of care); Practitioner Role resource (i.e., a specific set of roles, locations, specialties or services that a care provider may perform at an institution during a period of time); and Organization resource (i.e., a formally or informally recognized grouping of people or institutions organized for the purpose of achieving some form of collective action). For each CRUD request a valid JSON Web Token (JWT) following the standard RFC 7519 [29] is required. Every time that a request arrives, the JWT is validated in order to be possible to access the requested information. This is one of the security measures to confine the information to undue requests. Moreover, the requests are all submitted to the authorization service so the information can be retrieved according to permissions associated to a specific role. The JWT is used by the authorization service to get the role, so that rules previously defined are applied for the decision if the requested operation can or cannot be achieved. For positive decisions, the persistence service is responsible to perform the requested operation. Considering a Read request, some fields can be omitted according to usersâ€™ permissions. The other operations (i.e., Create, Update or Delete) can be permitted or denied. 3.2. Authentication The authentication component is supported by a REST architecture and allows the registration of specific users in the SOCIAL platform, the assignment of the respective roles and the verification of their identities [27]. If a user authentication is successfully validated, the service returns a JWT. This JWT enables the secure exchange of information between parties and has attributes for the verification of the user identity so that information accesses can be authorized. One of the available JWT attributes is the role that identifies the profile with which the user is currently operating. The role acts as a permission aggregator that is managed by the authorization component. Since a JWT is present in the all the communications between the various components of the SOCIAL platform, each one of these components holds an encrypted private key to verify veracity and validity of the JWT they received. 3.3. Authorization The FHIR resources may have security labels for three different purposes: to indicate the permissions related to information operations, such as Create or Read; to indicate what resources can be returned; and to indicate how specific information should be dealt with. Requests can also add their own security labels (e.g., break-the-glass protocol to allow a physician dealing with an emergency to access information of patient even when has not access permissions). The security label can have different categorizations, such as confidentiality, sensitivity, compartment, integrity or handling. Integrating Attribute-based Access Control (ABAC) or Role-based Access Control (RBAC) mechanisms with FHIR is possible, since the FHIR resources are also defined by their attributes. The eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) [30] is a standard that allows handling requests, regarding data access, using an ABAC policy language. These requests related to the access of specific resources are analyzed through a set of rules, so that a decision can be achieved. By using XACML, pre-established rules can be divided into different categories. The decision for the access request is obtained after comparing all the values of the attributes of the respective categories, between the request and the previously defined rules. Depending on how a specific decision rule was defined, a request result can be a denial or a permit. Furthermore, policies and their respective rules can have different levels of detail, according to the different number of attributes needed before reaching a decision [27]. 6 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 3.4. Logging and Auditing The logging and auditing component, as the remainder components, is based on a REST architecture, allowing the communication of the different services and applications of the SOCIAL platform via HTTP. A cryptographic secure blockchain was adopted, which stores the events and the blocks (of the blockchain) in a special purpose database. Moreover, audit processes will access the stored events and blocks to determine the relevant data. For that three separate processes were considered: log insertion, log consensus and log audit [27]. Log insertion is triggered when a service event occurs in the SOCIAL platform. The data describing the event is sent to the logging service as an HTTP Post with the event inserted in its request body, as a JSON Object. The service processes its contents and categorizes the different elements involved in the event (e.g., date, user or application), so that it can construct the appropriate document to be persisted. These requests must also have a JWT, which is used to verify signatures (using an algorithm and a secret key previously established) and to validate requested events. The log integrity is validated locally upon block insertion, which happens at fixed intervals. Inserting a block requires the validation of the previous blocks in the chain (either by that service or offloaded to horizontally scalable instances), and the registration of the log entries that are pending to be inserted. This creates interdependencies between log entries from multiple sources, limiting single source spoofing by an adversary. Log consensus is achieved by sending data from the blocks inserted between two wider time frames, to application or services belonging to the same ecosystem, which should reply with proofs of integrity. Each proof contains a digital signature, which may follow the standard X.509 time stamping practices. It can consist of full logs, allowing the effective replication of the entire event log and block chain in external services. However, only minimal indirect validation is possible, by synchronizing the block chain without actual log data, which is a tradeoff between performance and resilience to failures as well as audit effectiveness. Log audit is done by direct observation of the event stream stored in the database. Existing tools such as Kibana can be used and the integrity of the data observed can be assured. The integrity of the chain can be verified anytime to check for any inconsistencies. Since every block of the chain has a clear identification, with fingerprints of the log data, as well as time stamps of the first and last event during that time period, the hash of all the events occurred between two checkpoints can be recalculated to check if it matches the one stored in the block. The next and previous hash fields on every block can also be used to verify if the block itself has not been tampered. 4. For that, the functional requirements of the social support office from one municipality involved in the project were considered, according to a user-centered approach [31]. A social support office intends to support older adults living independently by answer to various types of assistance requests and deliver several programs to promote quality of life and active ageing. In this respect, a request for assistance must be understood as the possibility to create requests for specific needs or to report an anomalous situation. In turn, programs are initiatives composed by different types of activities, such as physical activity (e.g., swimming or marching), and sociocultural activities (e.g., theatre or dance) [2]. Therefore, different actors must be considered as well different types of applications [2]. In terms of actors there are care receivers and their informal caregivers (e.g., to request for assistance, to access to information, plans or notifications, to apply, register and withdraw programs and activities, or to provide feedback); help desk assistants (e.g., to provide information of certain activities to potential participants or to enroll participants), case managers (e.g., to access to plans and notifications); operational assistants and external entities (e.g., to know actions to be performed), head of the social support office (e.g., allocation of human, material and economic resources), and member of the City Council (e.g., evaluation of the performance of the social support office). During the pilot set-up, it was carried out the consolidation of all the registries of all the databases related to citizens requiring social services of the municipality. Introduction The human functioning concept explains the interrelation between body structures and functions, individual activity and participation in society [1], and has become progressively more important due to the increasing of the average life expectancy and the consequent prevalence of chronic-related diseases [2]. The International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) [3] is based on a biopsychosocial approach that considers the functioning and health conditions depend on physical, personal and environmental aspects. The ICF belongs to the World Health Organization (WHO) family of classifications, the World Health Organization Family of International Classifications (WHO-FIC), along with the International Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems and the International Classification of Health Interventions, still under development. The primary aspect is the conceptualization of disability as a result of a set of situations and conditions that, in addition to health conditions, include the environment, living conditions as well as personal factors. Accordingly, the disabled individual is not seen as an individual with a disability, even though temporary, because the emphasis must be given to all the components that can favor or limit the performance of the various functions, both biological and social. Therefore, ICF advocates a shift from a disease-based view to a view based on the individualsâ€™ functioning as an essential component of health [3]. That is, unlike other models, the ICF considers a positive perspective for the functioning, but which, nevertheless, allows assess the degree of functional loss. Thus, ICF components, such as body structures, organ and system functions, activities, participation and environmental conditions, allow identifying what the individuals may or may not be able to do in their daily life [3]. A clinical classification aims to codify observations and interventions in accordance with standardized codes. In particular, the ICF is a hierarchical classification that uses an alphanumeric system. The letters b, s, d and e are used to denote the four domains of ICF, respectively, body functions, body structures, activities and participation, and environmental factors. Each domain is organized by chapters, where the letters are followed by the chapter number (digit). The next two digits represent the second level, followed by the third level (one digit), and lastly, the fourth level (one digit). The levels represent different resolution grades of the classification, that is, the broader categories may contain more detailed subcategories. For example, the Mobility (d4) chapter is included in the Activities and Participation (d) domain and includes several subcategories, such as â€˜walking and movingâ€™ (d450-d469), Â´changing and maintaining body positionâ€™ (d410-d429) and â€˜carrying, moving and handling objectsâ€™ (d430 -d449). It is possible to assign codes of different levels to the individual, which may be independent or interrelated [3]. For what has been presented, the ICF is conceptually very rich, so the coding process, i.e., the translation of clinical information collected and clinical interventions carried out in ICF codes, is a complex process, taking into account the diversity of the concepts involved, as well as the number of existing codes to codify such concepts. Moreover, it is also a process with some subjectivity, since the same information can be evaluated and classified differently by different encoders [2]. For that reason, the scientific literature reports coding processes carried out by two independent encoders who follow certain rules, with differences resolved by consensus, involving sometimes a third encoder [11]. Exacerbating this situation considerably, the degree of agreement between encoders is dependent on the knowledge they have about ICF, experience, education or professional training, and the type of information they pretend to codify. This compromises an adequate organization of the information to obtain epidemiological knowledge about populationsâ€™ functioning, disability and quality of life. Consequently, the development of tools based on information technologies to support ICF coding can contribute decisively to its operationalization. To the best of the authors' knowledge, the scientific literature does not report the existence of such tools. 3. Objectives The ICF offers a systematic and meaningful ordering of information associated with human functioning, allowing the representation of an individualsâ€™ functional profile through the coding of clinical observations and interventions performed according to universal categories [12]. Two coding methods can be used for this. One can use previously validated qualifiers to codify the gathered information, while in another, each item of the collected information is codified casuistically [11]. Regardless of the method employed, as a result of the coding process it is possible to obtain a functioning profile. This, of course, may be more or less detailed, depending on the number of ICF categories used. Thus, the coding is dependent on the granularity (amount of codes considered essential for the profile), the experience of the encoders, and the greater or lesser alignment of the clinical evaluation instruments used (e.g., to codify the results of a functioning assessment instrument such as WHODAS II, a ICF-based instrument, is substantially easier than to codify information resulting from other evaluation instruments that are not directly based on the ICF). As an example of coding it is possible to consider the following therapeutic objective: â€˜to explore a toy with both hands for five minutes, without bringing it to the mouth, under the guidance of a relativeâ€™. The ICF code d1310 (i.e., â€˜learning through simple actions with a single objectâ€™) can be used to codify the action â€˜to explore a toy with both 4 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 handsâ€™. However, if the aim is also to consider the environmental factors then the ICF code e310 (â€˜immediate familyâ€™) must also be considered. In order to optimize the ICF coding, it is possible to record all the codifications made, namely those that have been consensual, and based on that register, be able to provide suggestions for each new item to be codified. In this way, when in the presence of previously codified items, an increase in the level of agreement between encoders is predicted. For example, if the goal is to codify the expression â€˜sit in the toiletâ€™, an encoder may feel tempted to encode this expression with code d4103 (i.e., â€˜sit - adopt a seated position with folded legsâ€™). If this expression had previously been codified, other options than code d4103 could be suggested, thus reducing the probability of error. In order to minimize the difficulties associated with ICF coding, the authors have developed a web platform that presents a friendly interface with a simple, intuitive and consistent design. In terms of requirements analysis, in addition to those involved in coding processes, the users, it was also considered the existence of an administrator actor, who among other functions, must ensure the validation of the information inserted. 4. Architecture The solution chosen for the implementation of the web platform, called International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health - Codification Platform (ICF-CP) [13], was the set of JavaScript-based technologies called MEAN (MongoDB, Express, Angular and Nodejs) Stack [14]. From the client to the server side, this solution is totally JavaScript. The client-side is responsible for the interaction with the user. For that, the client provides HyperText Markup Language (HTML) pages, which enable the execution of the different actions. Each HTML page is associated with a component which, in turn, defines a class that contains the data and application logic. When the user performs an operation on the HTML file, triggers a function in the corresponding component through an event binding. In terms of access to the database, a consolidated interface was sought. Thus, if data is required from the database, it is necessary to invoke a service, as this operate as a client-side wrapper for the RESTful Application Programming Interface (API) endpoints. Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) requests are performed in the services, allowing data to be sent and received for the components. The request is carried out with an HTTP instance, which allows to invoke get, put, post or delete methods by passing a Uniform Resource Locator (URL) that will be the endpoint and may contain several parameters in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format. The manipulation and handling of errors is performed with the help of an observable map and catch operators that are also imported. From the serversâ€™ point of view, each request is initially accessed by Node.js threading and then sent to the server using Express. This last framework allows to configure applications, add routes and rest endpoints to boot the middleware. On the server is defined the base path for the file where the endpoints/routes with the Create, Read, Update and Delete (CRUD) operations on the database (route.js) are located. In this file, an instance of the Express Router class is used to define RESTful API routes and several functions consisting of two arguments: a route and a callback function. If this route matches the URL sent in the HTTP request, then this function will be executed. The callback function contains the request and response objects as arguments. Within these functions, CRUD operations are performed on the MongoDB-supported database, with the help of Mongoose library-defined data models. The data models are schemas that map collections of MongoDB and define the format of the documents in it. However, the most popular client- side technologies are the Angular and React. After a comparative study between the two tools for the development of the frontend was chosen the Angular. Both have their advantages and disadvantages and are excellent technologies, though there was more willingness to learn the Angular, more specifically the version 2. Applications developed in Angular 2 are separated into three parts: HTML templates, classes (plan from which objects are created) of components that generate the templates, and services that contain the business logic of the application. Validation With the objective of evaluating the impact of the described platform, an experimental study was carried out to compare the levels of agreement between pair of encoders, with and without the platform. For this experimental study, it was used real data that resulted from a clinical study aiming to assess a rehabilitative approach based on contextual interventions for children with cerebral palsy or related neurological situations compared to the classical approach. The clinical study involved a total of 120 families from all over Portugal and ran for one year with weekly sessions. In all sessions, the clinicians recorded the therapeutic goals as well as the results of the interventions that were performed. From these records, for the validation of the platform, a set of therapeutic objectives (defined prior to the contextual intervention or objectives that were redefined after the interventions) were randomly selected from a total of ten sessions. To codify these registers a specific set of coding rules [11] adapted from Cieza et al. [15] were used. The validation of the platform proceeded in three distinct phases. Initially (phase 1), two encoders with similar experience with ICF coding independently coded the therapeutic goals without using the platform. Simultaneously, the encoders manually recorded the examples that they considered important to insert into the platform. After a process of comparison between the examples considered by the two encoders, and after the resolution of divergences by discussion until reaching the consensus, involving a third encoder, the suggestions were included in the platform (phase 2). Finally, in phase 3, two other encoders with a similar experience with ICF coding when compared with the phase 1 encoders, repeated the coding procedures using the platform described in this article. Moreover, in both phases the times each encoder spent in the coding process were recorded. In terms of results, an analysis was performed considering the ratio between the number of the total agreements and the total number of codifications made by the two pairs of encoders (i.e., phase 1 and phase 3). From this analysis there was a significant increase in the degree of agreement when the platform was used: the degree of agreement increased from 61.4% in phase 1 to 77.5% in phase 3. Additionally, it was verified that during phase 1, 8 Author name / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2018) 000â€“000 without the platform, the time spent in the coding process by both phase 1 encoders was 350 minutes, while phase 3 encoders spent 130 minutes to codify the same registers using the platform. 7. Conclusion and Future Work In this article, the authors presented the development of a web platform, the ICF-CP, aiming to provide a user- friendly interface for coding clinical observations and interventions. An experimental study was carried out to compare the levels of agreement between pair of encoders and we may conclude that the platform can facilitate the ICF coding process by increasing the level of agreement and reducing the time spent by the encoders. Further research is planned to assess the performance of the platform with additional real data, including results of the interventions in addition to therapeutic goals, as well to evaluate the usability of the platform and to determine features to be included to further optimize the ICF coding process.
